question: Question 1 The shaft of a 6 m wide gate in the figure will fail at a moment of 3924 kN.m about the hinge P. The maximum value of water depth [latex] h [/latex] (in m) that the gate can hold is __________ (round off to the nearest integer). Note: Density of water = [latex] 1000 , \text{kg/m}^3 [/latex] Acceleration due to gravity = [latex] 9.81 , \text{m/s}^2 [/latex]

Question 2 The drag force, [latex]F_D[/latex], on a sphere due to a fluid flowing past the sphere is a function of viscosity, [latex]\mu[/latex], the mass density, [latex]\rho[/latex], the velocity of flow, [latex]V[/latex], and the diameter of the sphere, [latex]D[/latex]. Pick the relevant (one or more) non-dimensional parameter(s) pertaining to the above process from the following list.
solution: We apply Buckingham Pi theorem. Given variables are: [latex]F_D, \mu, \rho, V, D[/latex]-> Total 5 variables Fundamental dimensions involved: [M], [L], [T] -> 3 So, number of non-dimensional groups = 5 - 3 = 2 Two commonly known non-dimensional numbers in this context: Drag Coefficient: [latex]C_D = \dfrac{F_D}{\rho V^2 D^2}[/latex] Reynolds Number: [latex]Re = \dfrac{\rho V D}{\mu}[/latex] Let's now analyze the options: (A) [latex]\dfrac{F_D}{\rho V^2 D^2}[/latex]   Correct (Drag coefficient) (B) [latex]\dfrac{\rho F_D}{V^2 D^2}[/latex]  Incorrect (Not dimensionless) (C) [latex]\dfrac{\rho V D}{\mu}[/latex]   Correct (Reynolds number) (D) [latex]\dfrac{\mu \rho}{V D}[/latex]   Incorrect (Has dimensions)

question: Question 3 Consider flow in a long and very wide rectangular open channel. Width of the channel can be considered as infinity compared to the depth of flow.  Uniform flow depth is 1.0 m. The bed slope of the channel is 0.0001. The Manning roughness coefficient value is 0.02. Acceleration due to gravity, [latex]g[/latex] can be taken as [latex]9.81\ \text{m/s}^2[/latex]. The critical depth (in m) corresponding to the flow rate resulting from the above conditions is ______ (round off to one decimal place).
solution: Given: Uniform depth, [latex]y = 1.0\ \text{m}[/latex] Slope, [latex]S = 0.0001[/latex] Manning's [latex]n = 0.02[/latex] [latex]g = 9.81\ \text{m/s}^2[/latex] Since the channel is very wide, hydraulic radius [latex]R \approx y = 1.0\ \text{m}[/latex] Discharge per unit width ([latex]q[/latex]) using Manning's equation for wide channel: [latex]q = \frac{1}{n} y^{5/3} S^{1/2}[/latex] [latex]q = \frac{1}{0.02} (1.0)^{5/3} (0.0001)^{1/2} = 50 \times 0.01 = 0.5\ \text{m}^2/\text{s}[/latex] Now, to find critical depth [latex]y_c[/latex], use the critical flow condition: [latex]q^2 = \frac{g y_c^3}{1}[/latex] for a wide rectangular channel [latex]y_c = \left(\frac{q^2}{g}\right)^{1/3} = \left(\frac{0.5^2}{9.81}\right)^{1/3}[/latex] [latex]y_c = \left(\frac{0.25}{9.81}\right)^{1/3} = (0.02549)^{1/3} \approx 0.295\ \text{m}[/latex] Rounded to one decimal place: [latex]\boxed{0.3\ \text{m}}[/latex]

question: Question 4 Consider steady flow of water in the series pipe system shown below, with specified discharge. The diameters of Pipes A and B are 2 m and 1 m, respectively. The lengths of Pipes A and B are 100 m and 200 m, respectively. Assume the Darcy-Weisbach friction coefficient, [latex]f[/latex] as 0.01 for both the pipes. The ratio of head loss in Pipe-B to the head loss in Pipe-A is ______ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution:
Given Data (from the figure): Pipe A:
[latex]
D_A = 2 \ \text{m}, \quad L_A = 100 \ \text{m}, \quad f = 0.01
[/latex] Pipe B:
[latex]
D_B = 1 \ \text{m}, \quad L_B = 200 \ \text{m}, \quad f = 0.01
[/latex] Frictional Head Loss Formula (Darcy-Weisbach): [latex]
h_f = f \cdot \frac{L}{D} \cdot \frac{v^2}{2g}
[/latex] Since discharge is same, velocity is related to diameter: [latex]
Q = A \cdot v \Rightarrow v \propto \frac{1}{A} \propto \frac{1}{D^2} \Rightarrow v \propto \frac{1}{D^2}
[/latex] So,
[latex]
v^2 \propto \frac{1}{D^4}
[/latex] Ratio of head losses: [latex]
\frac{h_{f,B}}{h_{f,A}} = \frac{f \cdot \frac{L_B}{D_B} \cdot \frac{1}{D_B^4}}{f \cdot \frac{L_A}{D_A} \cdot \frac{1}{D_A^4}} = \frac{L_B}{L_A} \cdot \frac{D_A^5}{D_B^5}
[/latex] Substitute values: [latex]
\frac{h_{f,B}}{h_{f,A}} = \frac{200}{100} \cdot \left( \frac{2}{1} \right)^5 = 2 \cdot 32 = 64
[/latex]

question: Question 5 Consider a velocity vector, [latex]\vec{V}[/latex] in  [latex](x, y, z) [/latex] coordinates given below. Pick one or more CORRECT statement(s) from the choices given below. [latex]\vec{V} = u \vec{x} + v \vec{y}[/latex]
solution:
Given: [latex]\vec{V} = u(x, y)\vec{x} + v(x, y)\vec{y}[/latex] Step 1: Compute Curl of velocity Curl of a vector field in Cartesian coordinates is given by: [latex]
abla 	imes \vec{V} = \left|  egin{array}{ccc} \vec{x} & \vec{y} & \vec{z} \  rac{\partial}{\partial x} &  rac{\partial}{\partial y} &  rac{\partial}{\partial z} \ u & v & 0 \ \end{array} ight|[/latex] Expanding the determinant, we get: [latex]
abla 	imes \vec{V} = \left(  rac{\partial (0)}{\partial y} -  rac{\partial v}{\partial z} ight)\vec{x} - \left(  rac{\partial (0)}{\partial x} -  rac{\partial u}{\partial z} ight)\vec{y} + \left(  rac{\partial v}{\partial x} -  rac{\partial u}{\partial y} ight)\vec{z}[/latex] So, z-component of curl is: [latex](
abla 	imes \vec{V})_z =  rac{\partial v}{\partial x} -  rac{\partial u}{\partial y}[/latex] So, option (A) is correct. Option (B) is incorrect. Step 2: Compute Divergence of velocity Divergence is given by: [latex]
abla \cdot \vec{V} =  rac{\partial u}{\partial x} +  rac{\partial v}{\partial y}[/latex] So, option (C) is correct. Option (D) is incorrect.

options.A: z-component of Curl of velocity; [latex]\nabla \times \vec{V} = \left( \frac{\partial v}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} \right) \vec{z}[/latex]
options.B: z-component of Curl of velocity; [latex]\nabla \times \vec{V} = \left( \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} \right) \vec{z}[/latex]
options.C: Divergence of velocity; [latex]\nabla \cdot \vec{V} = \left( \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} + \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} \right)[/latex]
options.D: Divergence of velocity; [latex]\nabla \cdot \vec{V} = \left( \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} + \frac{\partial v}{\partial x} \right)[/latex]

question: Question 6 A hydraulic jump occurs in an open channel when the slope of the channel changes from ______.
solution: A hydraulic jump occurs when there is a sudden change in the flow characteristics of the fluid. This phenomenon typically occurs when the flow transitions from a high velocity (steep slope) to a lower velocity (mild slope). The change in slope causes a sudden rise in water level and a loss of kinetic energy, resulting in a turbulent flow downstream. Thus, the correct answer is (B) STEEP slope to MILD slope .

options.D: STEEP slope to a STEEPER slope

question:
Question 7 A 5.0 m wide rectangular channel carries a discharge of [latex]10 \mathrm{~m}^3 / \mathrm{s}[/latex] at a depth of 1.5 m under uniform flow. To produce critical flow conditions without aflecting the upstream conditions, the channel bottom elevation should be raised (in m) by _________
 (rounded oft to 2 decimal places). Assume that there is no loss of head at the raise, kinetic energy correction factor is 1.0 , and acceleration due to gravity is [latex]9.81 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^2[/latex].
solution: Given: Channel width, [latex]b = 5.0\ \text{m}[/latex] Discharge, [latex]Q = 10\ \text{m}^3/\text{s}[/latex] Initial flow depth, [latex]y = 1.5\ \text{m}[/latex] [latex]g = 9.81\ \text{m/s}^2[/latex] Step 1: Calculate flow per unit width: [latex]q = \frac{Q}{b} = \frac{10}{5} = 2.0\ \text{m}^2/\text{s}[/latex] Step 2: Critical depth for rectangular channel: [latex]y_c = \left( \frac{q^2}{g} \right)^{1/3} = \left( \frac{2.0^2}{9.81} \right)^{1/3} = (0.4077)^{1/3} = 0.740\ \text{m}[/latex] Step 3: Specific energy at initial condition: [latex]E_1 = y + \frac{v^2}{2g}[/latex] [latex]v = \frac{Q}{A} = \frac{10}{5 \times 1.5} = 1.33\ \text{m/s}[/latex] [latex]E_1 = 1.5 + \frac{(1.33)^2}{2 \cdot 9.81} = 1.5 + \frac{1.7689}{19.62} = 1.5 + 0.0902 = 1.5902\ \text{m}[/latex] Step 4: Specific energy at critical condition: [latex]E_c = \frac{3}{2} y_c = \frac{3}{2} \cdot 0.740 = 1.11\ \text{m}[/latex] Step 5: Bottom raise required: [latex]z = E_1 - E_c = 1.5902 - 1.11 = 0.48\ \text{m}[/latex] Answer: [latex]\boxed{0.48\ \text{m}}[/latex]

question:
Question 8 A hydraulic jump is formed in a 5 m wide rectangular channel, which has a horizontal bed and is carrying a discharge of [latex]15 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]. The depth of water upstream of the jump is 0.5 m . The power dissipated by the jump (in kW) is _________
 (rounded off to the nearest integer). Note: Acceleration due to gravity [latex]=9.81 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}[/latex] Density of water [latex]=1000 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Kinetic energy correction factor [latex]=1.0[/latex]
Question 9 For the Bernoulli's equation to be applicable in a fluid flow situation, which of the following conditions is/are to be satisfied:
solution: Bernoulli's equation is applicable under the following assumptions: (A) Fluid should be frictionless - no energy loss due to viscosity. (B) Fluid should be incompressible - [latex]\rho = \text{constant}[/latex] (C) Flow should be steady - [latex]\frac{\partial}{\partial t} = 0[/latex] (D) Flow should be rotational - Incorrect , because Bernoulli's equation assumes irrotational flow. Hence, the correct conditions are: (A), (B), and (C)

question: Question 10 For a flowing fluid, a dimensionless combination of velocity ([latex]V[/latex]), length scale ([latex]l[/latex]), and acceleration due to gravity ([latex]g[/latex]) would be
solution: Let us write their dimensional formulas: [latex][V] = LT^{-1}[/latex] [latex][l] = L[/latex] [latex][g] = LT^{-2}[/latex] Now, check the dimensional consistency of each option: Option (A): [latex]\frac{V^2}{gl}[/latex] [latex]= \frac{(LT^{-1})^2}{(LT^{-2})(L)} = \frac{L^2T^{-2}}{L^2T^{-2}} = 1[/latex] This expression is dimensionless. Option (B): [latex]\frac{Vg}{l}[/latex] [latex]= \frac{(LT^{-1})(LT^{-2})}{L} = \frac{L^2T^{-3}}{L} = LT^{-3}[/latex] This is not dimensionless. Option (C): [latex]\frac{gl^2}{V}[/latex] [latex]= \frac{(LT^{-2})(L^2)}{LT^{-1}} = \frac{L^3T^{-2}}{LT^{-1}} = L^2T^{-1}[/latex] This is not dimensionless. Option (D): [latex]\frac{l}{V^2g}[/latex] [latex]= \frac{L}{(LT^{-1})^2 \cdot LT^{-2}} = \frac{L}{L^3T^{-4}} = L^{-2}T^4[/latex] This is not dimensionless. Final Answer: [latex]\frac{V^2}{gl}[/latex] is the correct dimensionless combination.

After unplugging the orifice, the time (in seconds) taken for the water level to drop from [latex] 5 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] to [latex] 3.5 \mathrm{~m} [/latex] under free discharge condition is _____ (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution: Let at any instant depth of liquid in tank is ' [latex] h [/latex] ' [latex] m [/latex] and in time (dt), the depth falls by (-dh) [latex] \Rightarrow\left(C_{d} \cdot\left(\frac{\pi d^{2}}{4}\right) \sqrt{2 g h}\right) d t=A_{0}(-d h) [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{t}=\int \mathrm{dt}=\frac{\mathrm{A}_{0}}{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{d}} \cdot \frac{\pi \mathrm{d}^{2}}{4} \sqrt{2 \mathrm{~g}}} \int_{\mathrm{H}_{1}}^{\mathrm{H}_{2}}\left(\frac{-\mathrm{dH}}{\sqrt{\mathrm{h}}}\right) [/latex] [latex] t=\frac{A_{0}}{C_{d} \cdot \frac{\pi d^{2}}{4} \sqrt{2 g}}\left[2\left(\sqrt{\mathrm{H}_{1}}-\sqrt{\mathrm{H}_{2}}\right)\right] [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{t}=\left[\frac{2 \times 1.5 \mathrm{~m}^{2}}{0.6 \times \frac{\pi}{4}(0.1)^{2} \mathrm{~m}^{2} \sqrt{2 \times 10 \frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{s}^{2}}}} \times 2(\sqrt{5}-\sqrt{3.5}) \mathrm{m}^{1 / 2}\right] \mathrm{sec} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{t}=103.985 \mathrm{sec} [/latex]

Question 15 The following figure shows a plot between shear stress and velocity gradient for
materials/fluids P, Q, R, S, and T. Which one of the following options is CORRECT?
solution: Various types of newtonian \& non-newtonian fluids are shown in the figure. Fluids which obeys Newton's law of viscosity [latex] \left(\tau=\mu \frac{\mathrm{du}}{\mathrm{dy}}\right) [/latex] are called Newtonian Fluids and those fluids which do not obey this rule are called Non-Newtonian Fluids. General relationship between shear stress and velocity gradient is given by [latex] \tau=\mathrm{A}\left(\frac{\mathrm{du}}{\mathrm{dy}}\right)^{\mathrm{n}}+\mathrm{B} [/latex] In the figures shown above, slope of the curve is called apparent viscosity. Fluid for which apparent viscosity increases with du/dy are called Dilatant. Dilatant fluids are also called shear thickening fluids. Examples of dilatant fluids are solution with suspended starch or sand, sugar in water. Fluids for which apparent viscosity decreases with du/dy are called Pseudo Plastic. Pseudo plastic fluid are also called shear thinning fluid. Examples are paints, polymer solutions, blood, paper pulp, syrup, molasses, milk, gelatine. Bingham Plastic (ideal plastic) fluids require a certain minimum shear stress [latex] t_{y} [/latex] (yield stress) before they start flowing. Examples: tooth paste, sewage sludge, drilling mud have time dependent Newtonian Behaviour.

options.A: P [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Ideal Fluid; Q [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Ideal Bingham plastic; R [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Non-Newtonian fluid; S [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Newtonian fluid
options.B: P [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Real solid; Q [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Ideal Bingham plastic; S [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Newtonian fluid; T [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Ideal Fluid
options.C: P [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Ideal Fluid; Q [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Ideal Bingham plastic; R [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Non-Newtonian fluid; T [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Real solid
options.D: P [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Real solid; Q [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Newtonian fluid; R [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Ideal Bingham plastic; T [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] Ideal Fluid

solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
P_{P}+(800)(10)(4)&=\left(10^{3}\right)(10)(10), \quad \text { where } P_{p} \text { is pressure at } P\\

P_{P}+\left(32 \times 10^{3}\right)&=\left(100 \times 10^{3}\right)\\
 P_{P}&=68 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~Pa}\\
 P_{P}&=68 \mathrm{kPa}\end{aligned}[/latex] Now, force on PQR, [latex] F=\left[\frac{1}{2}(68+100) 4+\frac{1}{2}(100+160) 6\right] 5=(336+780) 5 =5580 \mathrm{kN}[/latex]

Question 25 Which of the following options match the test reporting conventions with the given material tests in the table? [latex]
\begin{array}{|l|l|}
\hline
\text{Test reporting convention} & \text{Material test} \\
\hline
\text{(P) Reported as ratio} & \text{(I) Solubility of bitumen} \\
\hline
\text{(Q) Reported as percentage} & \text{(II) Softening point of bitumen }\\
\hline
\text{(R) Reported in temperature} & \text{(III) Los Angeles abrasion test} \\
\hline
\text{(S) Reported in length} & \text{(IV) Flash point of bitumen} \\
\hline
 & \text{(V) Ductility of bitumen} \\
\hline
 & \text{(VI) Specific gravity of bitumen} \\
\hline
 & \text{(VII) Thin film oven test} \\
\hline
\end{array}
[/latex]
solution:
(I) Solubility of bitumen: It is defined as weight of bitumen soluble in [latex]100 \mathrm{ml}[/latex] of carbon disulphide. (II) Softening point of bitumen: It is the temperature at which bitumen attains a particular degree of softneess. (III) Los angles abrasion test: It is reported as
percentage of material finer than [latex]1.7 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] with respect to total weight. (IV) Flash point of bitumen: It is the lowest temperature at which bitumen catch five momentarily. (V) Ductility of bitumen: Ductility is measured by stretching a standard briquette of bitumen. The distance in [latex]\mathrm{cm}[/latex] that the briquette can be stretched before breaking is the ductility. (VI) Specific gravity of bitumen: It is the ratio of unit weight of bitumen to unit weight of water. (VII) Thin film oven test: It measure mass charge a sample as a percent of initial mass.

question: Question 26 A jet of water having a velocity of [latex]20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] strikes a series of plats fixed radially on a wheel revolving in the same direction a the jet at [latex]15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]. What is the percentage efficiency of the plates ? (round off to one decimal place).
solution:
Given water jet velocity [latex]\left(V_{1}\right)=20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] Wheel velocity [latex](u)=15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] [latex]F_{x}=\rho A V_{1}\left(V_{1}-u\right)[/latex] [latex]\%[/latex] efficiency of the plates [latex]\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{F_{x} u \times 100}{\frac{1}{2} \rho Q V_{1}^{2}} \\
& =\frac{P \times Q\left(V_{1}-u\right) u \times 100}{\frac{1}{2} \rho Q V_{1}^{2}} \\
& =\frac{2\left(V_{1}-u\right) u \times 100}{V_{1}^{2}} \\
& =\frac{2(20-15) \times 15}{20^{2}} \times 100 \\
& =37.5 \%
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

Question 29 Two discrete spherical particles (P and Q) of equal mass density are
independently released in water. Particle P and particle Q have diameters of
0.5 mm and 1.0 mm, respectively. Assume Stokes' law is valid. The drag force on particle Q will be________ times the drag force on particle P.
(round off to the nearest integer)
solution:
In case of discrete particle settling and Stoke's
law valid, at terminal velocity, since there is no
change in velocity, the net force on the body
is zero. Hence, [latex]F_D=\left ( \frac{\pi}{6}D^3\rho _sg-\frac{\pi}{6}D^3\rho _sg \right )=\frac{\pi}{6}gD^3(\rho _s-\rho _f) [/latex] For density of medium 
[latex](\rho _f) [/latex] and mass density of sphere [latex](\rho _s) [/latex] constant, Drag force [latex](F_D)\propto D^3 [/latex] For particle P, diameter [latex](D_P)=0.5 mm [/latex] For particle Q, diameter [latex](D_Q)=1 mm [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \frac{(F_D)_Q}{(F_D)_P}=\frac{(D_Q)^3}{(D_P)^3}=\left ( \frac{1}{0.5} \right )^3=8 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow (F_D)_Q=8 \times (F_D)P[/latex]

question:
Question 30 A pump with an efficiency of 80% is used to draw groundwater from a well for
irrigating a flat field of area 108 hectares. The base period and delta for paddy
crop on this field are 120 days and 144 cm, respectively. Water application
efficiency in the field is 80%. The lowest level of water in the well is 10 m
below the ground. The minimum required horse power (h.p.) of the pump is
________. (round off to two decimal places) (Consider 1 h.p. = 746 W; unit weight of water = 9810 [latex]N/m^3[/latex])
solution:
Base period (B) = 120 days [latex]\begin{aligned}
Delta (\Delta )&=144 cm=1.44m\\
Duty(D)&=\frac{8.64B}{\Delta }=\frac{8.64 \times 120}{1.44}\\
D&=720\frac{hec}{cumec}\\
Q&=\frac{Area}{D}=\frac{108}{720}=\frac{3}{20}m^3/s\\
Q_{applied}&=\frac{Q}{\eta _a}=\frac{3}{20 \times 0.8}=\frac{3}{16}\\
\text{Power required}&=\frac{mgh}{t}\\
&=\rho _w \times \left ( \frac{volume}{t} \right )g \times h\\
&=\rho _w Qgh=\gamma Qh\\
&=9810 \times \frac{3}{16} \times 10\\
&=\frac{73575}{4}watt
\end{aligned} [/latex] Horse power of pump  [latex]= \frac{\text{Power required}}{746 \times \text{efficiency}}=\frac{73575}{4 \times 746 \times 0.8}=30.82hp [/latex]

question:
Question 31 A hydraulic jump takes place in a 6 m wide rectangular channel at a point where
the upstream depth is 0.5 m (just before the jump). If the discharge in the
channel is 30 [latex]m^3/s[/latex] and the energy loss in the jump is 1.6 m, then the Froude
number computed at the end of the jump is ___________. (round off to two
decimal places)
(Consider the acceleration due to gravity as 10 [latex]m/s^2[/latex].)
solution:
[latex]Q=30m^3/sec [/latex] [latex]B=6m [/latex] [latex]y_1=0.5m [/latex] [latex]E_L=1.6m [/latex] [latex]q= \frac{Q}{B} =\frac{30}{6}=5m^3/sec/m [/latex] We know that, [latex]\begin{aligned}
E_L=\frac{(y_2-y_1)^3}{4y_1y_2}&=1.6m\\
\frac{(y_2-0.5)^3}{4 \times 0.5 \times y_2}&=1.6\\
y_2^3-1.5y_2^2+0.75y_2-0.125&=3.2y_2\\
y_2=2.5m,-0.0527m,&-0.0947m
\end{aligned}
 [/latex] Hence,
[latex] y_2=2.5m[/latex] Post jump Froude's No. [latex](F_2)=\frac{V_2}{\sqrt{\sqrt{gy_2}}}=\frac{\left ( \frac{30}{6 \times 2.5} \right )}{\sqrt{10 \times 2.5}}=0.4 [/latex] [latex] [/latex]

Question 35 Depth of water flowing in a 3 m wide rectangular channel is 2 m. The channel carries a discharge of 12 [latex]m^3/s [/latex]. Take g = 9.8 [latex]m/s ^2[/latex]. The bed width (in m) at contraction, which just causes the critical flow, is _________ without changing the upstream water level. (round off to two decimal places)
solution:
Given: [latex]B = 3m, y = 2m, Q = 12 m^3
/sec[/latex] [latex] Velocity(v)=\frac{Q}{A} =\frac{12}{2 \times 3}=2m/sec [/latex] Specific energy at section (1-1) [latex]E=y+\frac{v^2}{2g}=2+\frac{2^2}{2 \times 9.8}=\frac{108}{49}m[/latex] When channel section is contracted to minimum
width and for constant discharge Q, the flow over
contracted section will be critical flow and under
the assumption that no energy loss has taken
place. [latex]E=E_c=\frac{108}{49}[/latex] We have that, [latex]E_c=\frac{3}{2}y_c[/latex] (for rectangular crosssection) [latex]y_c=\frac{2}{3}E_c=\frac{2}{3} \times \frac{108}{49}=\frac{72}{49}[/latex] For critical flow condition, [latex]\begin{aligned}
\frac{Q^2T}{gA^3}&=1\\
\frac{Q^2B_{min}}{g(B_{min} \times y_c)^3}&=1\\
(B_{min})^2&=\frac{Q^2}{gy_c^3}\\
B_{min}&=\left ( \frac{(12)^2}{9.8 \times \left ( \frac{72}{49} \right )^3} \right )^{1/2}\\
&=2.152m
\end{aligned}  [/latex]

solution:

h_{f1} &=h_{f2} \\ 
 \frac{8Q_1^2}{\pi ^2 g} \times \frac{fl}{D_1^5}&= \frac{8Q_2^2}{\pi ^2 g} \times \frac{fl}{D_2^5} \\

Question 38 With respect to fluid flow, match the following in Column X with Column Y: [latex]\begin{array}{|l|l|}\hline
 \text{Column X}& \text{Column Y}\\ \hline
\text{(P) Viscosity} & \text{(I) Mach number}\\ \hline
 \text{(Q) Gravity}&\text{(II) Reynolds number}\\ \hline
 \text{(R) Compressibility}&\text{(III) Euler number}\\ \hline
\text{(S) Pressure} &\text{(IV) Froude number}\\ \hline
\end{array}[/latex] Which one of the following combinations is correct?
solution: Reynold's number ([latex]R_e[/latex]) is defined when apart from inertial force, viscous forces are dominant. [latex]R_e=\frac{\text{Inertial force}}{\text{Viscous force}}[/latex] Froude?s number ([latex]F_e[/latex]): It is used when in addition to inertial force, gravity forces are important. [latex]F_e=\frac{\text{Inertial force}}{\text{Gravity force}}[/latex] Euler number ([latex]E_u[/latex]): It is used when apart from inertial force, only pressure forces are dominant. [latex]E_u=\frac{\text{Inertial force}}{\text{Pressure force}}[/latex] Mach number ([latex]M[/latex]): It is used when in addition to inertial force, compressibility forces are dominant [latex]M=\frac{\text{Inertial force}}{\text{Elastic force}}[/latex]

question: Question 39 A venturimeter as shown in the figure (not to scale) is connected to measure the flow of water in a vertical pipe of 20 cm diameter. Assume [latex]g=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}[/latex]. When the deflection in the mercury manometer is 15 cm, the flow rate (in lps, round off to two decimal places) considering no loss in the venturimeter is ___________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Discharge }(Q) &=C_{d} \frac{A_{1} A_{2}}{\sqrt{A_{1}^{2}-A_{2}^{2}}} \sqrt{2 g h} \\ h &=X\left(\frac{\rho_{m}}{\rho}-1\right)=0.15\left(\frac{13.6 \times 10^{3}}{10^{3}}-1\right) \\ &=1.89 \mathrm{~m}\\ Q &=\frac{A_{1} A_{2}}{A_{2} \sqrt{\left(\frac{A_{1}}{A_{2}}\right)^{2}-1}} \times \sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 1.89} \\&= \frac{\frac{\pi}{4}(0.2)^{2}}{\sqrt{(2)^{4}-1}} \times \sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 1.89} \\&= 49.395 \mathrm{l} / \mathrm{s} \simeq 49.40 \mathrm{l} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 A fire hose nozzle directs a steady stream of water of velocity 50 m/s at an angle of [latex]45^{\circ} [/latex] above the horizontal. The stream rises initially but then eventually falls to the ground. Assume water as incompressible and inviscid. Consider the density of air and the air friction as negligible, and assume the acceleration due to gravity as [latex]9.81 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}[/latex]. The maximum height (in m,round off to two decimal places) reached by the stream above the hose nozzle will then be _________
solution: As we know that [latex]\begin{aligned} {V}^{2}-u^{2}&=2 a S\\ \text{In vertical direction} (\uparrow)\\ 0^{2}-\left(50 \sin 45^{\circ}\right)^{2} &=2(-9.81) h_{\max } \\ h_{\max } &=\frac{\left(50 \sin 45^{\circ}\right)^{2}}{2(9.81)}=63.71 \mathrm{~m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 A rectangular open channel of 6 m width is carrying a discharge of [latex]20 \mathrm{~m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]. Consider the acceleration due to gravity as [latex]9.81 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}[/latex] and assume water as incompressible and inviscid. The depth of flow in the channel at which the specific energy of the flowing water is minimum for the given discharge will then be
solution: Minimum specific energy will correspond to a critical flow condition. The critical depth [latex]\begin{aligned} \left(Y_{C}\right) &=\left[\frac{q^{2}}{g}\right]^{1 / 3} \\ Y_{C} &=\left[\frac{(20 / 6)^{2}}{9.81}\right]^{1 / 3}=1.042 \mathrm{~m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 The ratio of the momentum correction factor to the energy correction factor for a laminar flow in a pipe is
solution: For laminar flow through pipe. [latex]\frac{\text { Momentum correction factor }}{\text { Kinetic energy correction factor }}=\frac{4 / 3}{2}=\frac{4}{6}=\frac{2}{3}[/latex]

question: Question 43 A cylinder (2.0 m diameter, 3.0 m long and 25 kN weight) is acted upon by water on one side and oil (specific gravity=0.8) on other side as shown in the figure. The absolute  ratio of the net magnitude of vertical forces to the net  magnitude of horizontal forces (round off to two decimal places) is _____________
solution: Net horizontal force [latex]\left(F_{H}\right)[/latex] due to liquids [latex]\begin{aligned} F_{H} &=F_{H 1}-F_{H 2} \\ &=\rho_{w} g \bar{h}_{1} A_{v_{1}}-\rho_{\mathrm{oil}} g \bar{h}_{2} A_{v_{2}} \\ &=\left(10^{3}\right)(9.81)\left(1+\frac{2}{2}\right)(2 \times 3)-(800)(9.81)\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)(1 \times 3) \\ F_{H} &=105.948 \mathrm{kN}(\rightarrow) \end{aligned}[/latex] Net vertical force  [latex]\left(F_{v}\right)[/latex] due to liquids [latex]\begin{aligned} F_{v} &=F_{1}+F_{2} \\ &=\rho_{w} g \forall_{1}+\rho_{o i l} g \forall_{2} \\ &=\left(10^{3}\right)(9.81)\left(\frac{\pi(1)^{2} \times 3}{2}\right)+(800)(9.81)\left(\frac{\pi}{4}(1)^{2} \times 3\right) \\ &=64.7199 \mathrm{kN}(\uparrow) \\ \frac{F_{V}}{F_{H}} &=\frac{64.7199}{105.948}=0.61 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 44 A fluid flowing steadily in a circular pipe of radius R has a velocity that is everywhere parallel to the axis (centerline) of the pipe. The velocity distribution  along the radial direction is [latex]V_r=U\left ( 1-\frac{r^2}{R^2} \right )[/latex], where [latex]r[/latex] is the radial distance as 
measured from the pipe axis and [latex]U[/latex] is the maximum velocity at [latex]r=0[/latex]. The average velocity of the fluid in the pipe is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} u&=U\left ( 1-\frac{r^2}{R^2} \right ) \\ \dot{m}&=\int_{0}^{R} \rho (2 \pi r\; dr)u\\ &= 2 \pi \rho U\int_{0}^{R} \left ( 1-\frac{r^2}{R^2} \right ) r\; dr\\ \rho (\pi R^2)\bar{u} &= 2 \pi \rho U \left ( \frac{R^2}{2}-\frac{R^4}{R^2 \times 4} \right )\\ \bar{u}&= \frac{U}{2}\\ \bar{u} &= \text{Mean velocity} \\ U&=\text{Max velocity} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 If water is flowing at the same depth in most hydraulically efficient triangular and rectangular channel sections then the ratio of hydraulic radius of triangular section to that of rectangular section is
solution: Efficient channel section [latex]\begin{aligned} A & =y^{2} & & A=2 y^{2} \\ P & =2 \sqrt{2} y & P & =4 y \\ R_{I} & =\frac{y}{2 \sqrt{2}} & R_{I I}&=\frac{y}{2} \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad \qquad \frac{R_{I}}{R_{I I}} & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 47 A hydraulic jump occurs, in a triangular (V-shaped) channel with side slopes 1:1 (vertical
to horizontal). The sequent depths are 0.5 m and 1.5 m. The flow rate (in [latex]m^3/s[/latex], round
off to two decimal places) in the channel is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A &=\frac{1}{2} \times 2Y \times Y =Y^2 \\ \bar{Y} &=\frac{Y}{3} \end{aligned} [/latex] For a horizontal and frictionless channel Specific Force (F) [latex] =A\bar{Y}+\frac{Q^2}{Ag}=constant [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; Y^2\left ( \frac{Y}{3} \right )+\frac{Q^2}{(Y^2)g}=constant[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \; \frac{Y^3}{3}+\frac{Q^2}{gY^2}=constant [/latex] If [latex]Y_1[/latex] and [latex]Y_2[/latex] are conjugate depth [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{Y_1^3}{3}+\frac{Q^2}{gY_1^2} &= \frac{Y_2^3}{3}+\frac{Q^2}{gY_2}\\ \frac{0.5^3}{3}+\frac{Q^2}{g \times 0.5^2}&=\frac{1.5^3}{3}+\frac{Q^2}{g \times 1.5^2} \\ \frac{1.5^3}{3}-\frac{0.5^3}{3}&=\frac{Q^2}{g}\left ( \frac{1}{0.5^2}-\frac{1}{1.5^2} \right ) \\ Q&=1.728 m^3/sec \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 48 A cast iron pipe of diameter 600 mm and length 400 m carries water from a tank and
discharges freely into air at a point 4.5 m below the water surface in the tank. The friction
factor of the pipe is 0.018. Consider acceleration due to gravity as 9.81 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. The velocity
of the flow in pipe (in m/s, round off to two decimal places) is __________.
solution: Apply energy equation between (1) and (2) [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{P_1}{\rho g} +\frac{V_1^2}{2g}+z_1&= \frac{P_2}{\rho g} +\frac{V_2^2}{2g}+z_2+h_f\\ 4.5&=\frac{flV^2}{2gD}+0.5\frac{V^2}{2g}+\frac{V^2}{2g} \\ 4.5&=\frac{(0.018)(400)V^2}{2(9.81)(0.6)}+\frac{1.5V^2}{2g} \\ 4.5&=\frac{12V^2}{2g}+\frac{1.5V^2}{2g} \\ V^2&=6.54 \\ V&=2.557 m/s\simeq 2.56m/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 49 Two identically sized primary settling tanks receive water for Type-I settling (discrete
particles in dilute suspension) under laminar flow conditions. The surface overflow rate
(SOR) maintained in the two tanks are 30 [latex]m^3/m^2\cdot d[/latex] and 15 [latex]m^3/m^2\cdot d[/latex]. The lowest diameters
of the particles, which shall be settled out completely under SORs of 30 [latex]m^3/m^2\cdot d[/latex] and 15 [latex]m^3/m^2\cdot d[/latex] are
designated as [latex]d_{30}[/latex] and [latex]d_{15}[/latex] respectively. The ratio [latex]\frac{d_{30}}{d_{15}}[/latex]
(round off to two decimal places),
is __________.
solution: For type-I setting, Stokes law is applicable. [latex]\begin{aligned} V_s&\propto d^2 \\ \frac{d_{30}^2}{d_{15}^2}&=\frac{30}{15}=2 \\ \frac{d_{30}}{d_{15}}&=\sqrt{2}=1.41 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 50 Velocity distribution in a boundary layer is given by [latex]\frac{u}{U_\infty }=\sin \left ( \frac{\pi}{2}\frac{y}{\delta } \right )[/latex], where [latex]u[/latex] is the
velocity at vertical coordinate [latex]y, U_\infty[/latex] is the free stream velocity and [latex]\delta[/latex] is the boundary
layer thickness. The values of [latex] U_\infty[/latex] and [latex]\delta[/latex] are 0.3 m/s and 1.0 m, respectively. The velocity gradient [latex]\left ( \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} \right )[/latex] (in [latex]s^{-1}[/latex], round off to two decimal places) at y= 0, is ________.
solution: Given: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{u}{u_\infty }&=\sin \left ( \frac{\pi}{2} \frac{y}{\delta }\right )\\ u_\infty &=0.3 m/s\\ \delta &=1m\\ \frac{du}{dy}&=\frac{d}{dy}u_\infty \cdot \sin\left ( \frac{\pi}{2} \frac{y}{\delta } \right )\\ &=\frac{u_\infty \cdot \pi}{2\delta } \cos \left ( \frac{\pi}{2} \frac{y}{\delta } \right )\\ \text{At y=0 and} & \; \delta=1 \\ \left.\begin{matrix} \frac{du}{dy} \end{matrix}\right|_{y=0}&=\frac{0.3 \pi}{2(1)} \cos \left ( \frac{\pi}{2}\frac{0}{1} \right )\\ &=0.47 s^{-1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 51 The velocity components in the x and y directions for an incompressible flow are given
as u=(-5+6x) and v=-(9+6y), respectively. The equation of the streamline is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given  } \; \; \; & u=-5+6x \\ & v=-(9+6y) \end{aligned} [/latex] Equation of streamline [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dx}{u}&=\frac{dy}{u} \\ \frac{dx}{-5+6x}&=\frac{dy}{-(9+6y)} \\ \text{Integrating it,} \\ \ln(-5+6x)^{1/6}&= -\ln(9+6y)^{1/6}+ \ln C^{1/6}\\ \frac{1}{6} \ln (-5+6x)(9+6y)&=\frac{1}{6} \ln C \\ \text{Take antilog,} \\ (-5 + 6x)(9 + 6y) &= \text{constant} \\ \text{u.v} &= \text{constant} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 52 A circular water tank of 2 m diameter has a circular orifice of diameter 0.1 m at the bottom.
Water enters the tank steadily at a flow rate of 20 litre/s and escapes through the orifice.
The coefficient of discharge of the orifice is 0.8. Consider the acceleration due to gravity
as 9.81 [latex]m/s^2[/latex] and neglect frictional loses. The height of the water level (in m, round off
to two decimal places) in the tank at the steady state, is ______.
solution: Assume H is the level of weter in the tank in steady condition. For steady water level in the tank Discharge through orifice = Water enters in the tank [latex]\begin{aligned} c_d a \sqrt{2 gH}&=20 \times 10^{-3} \\ 0.8 \times \frac{\pi}{4} (0.1)^2 \sqrt{2gH}&=0.02 \\ H&=0.5164 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 53 Three reservoir P, Q and R are interconnected by pipes as shown in the figure (not drawn
to the scale). Piezometric head at the junction S of the pipes is 100 m. Assume
acceleration due to gravity as 9.81 m/[latex]s^2[/latex] and density of water as 1000 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex]. The length
of the pipe from junction S to the inlet of reservoir R is 180 m. Considering head loss only due to friction (with friction factor of 0.03 for all the pipes),
the height of water level in the lowermost reservoir R (in m, round off to one decimal
places) with respect to the datum, is ________.
solution: Apply conutinuity [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_3&=Q-1+Q_2 \\ &= A_1V_1+A_2V_2\\ &= \frac{\pi}{4}(0.3)^2(2.56)+\frac{\pi}{4}(0.3)^2(1.98)\\ &= 0.3209 m^3/s \end{aligned} [/latex] Apply energy eq. between (S) and (R) [latex]\begin{aligned} H_s&= H_r+h_f\\ 100&=+\frac{8Q_3^2}{\pi ^2 g} \times \frac{fL_3}{D_3^5} \\ 100 &=z+\frac{8(0.3209)^2}{\pi^2 g} \times \frac{(0.03)(180)}{(0.45)^5} \\ z&= 97.51 m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 54 Water flows at the rate of 12 [latex]m^3/s[/latex] in a 6 m wide rectangular channel. A hydraulic jump
is formed in the channel at a point where the upstream depth is 30 cm (just before the
jump). Considering acceleration due to gravity as 9.81 [latex]m/s^2[/latex] and density of water as 1000
[latex]kg/m^3[/latex], the energy loss in the jump is
solution: Assuming channle bed to be horizontal and frictionless. [latex]q=\frac{12}{6}=2 m^3/s/m[/latex] Initial Froude No. [latex]\begin{aligned} (F_r) &=\left ( \frac{q^2}{gY_1^3} \right )^{1/2} \\ &= \left ( \frac{2^2}{9.81 \times 0.3^3} \right )^{1/2}\\ &=3.88 \end{aligned} [/latex] From Belenger's Momentum equation for a rectangular channel [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{Y_2}{Y_1}&=\frac{1}{2}(-1+\sqrt{1+8F_1^2}) \\ &=\frac{1}{2}(-1+\sqrt{1+8\times 3.88^2}) \\ &= 5.018\\ Y_2&=5.018 \times 0.3=1.505m \end{aligned}[/latex] Heal loss in the jump [latex]\begin{aligned} (h_L) &=\frac{(Y_2-Y_1)^3}{4Y_1Y_2} \\ &= \frac{(1.505-0.3)^3}{4 \times 1.505 \times 0.3}\\ &= 0.968m \end{aligned}[/latex] Power lost in the jump [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\gamma _wQh_L \\ &= (9.81 \times 12 \times 0.968)kW\\ &=114.04 kW \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 55 A 4 m wide rectangular channel carries 6 [latex]m^3/s[/latex] of water. The Manning's 'n' of the open
channel is 0.02. Considering g = 9.81 [latex]m/s^2[/latex], the critical velocity of flow (in m/s, round
off to two decimal places) in the channel, is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Critical depth} \; (Y_c)&=\left ( \frac{q^2}{g} \right )^{1/3} \\ &=\left ( \frac{1.5^2}{9.81} \right )^{1/3} \\ &= 0.612m\\ \text{Critical velocity}\; (V_c)&=\sqrt{gY_c}=\sqrt{9.81 \times 0.612} \\ &= 2.45 m/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 56 Uniform flow with velocity U makes an angle [latex]\theta[/latex] with the y-axis, as shown in the figure The velocity potential ([latex]\Phi[/latex]), is
solution: Velocity in x-depth, [latex]u_x=u\sin \theta[/latex] Velocity in y-depth, [latex]u_y=u\cos \theta[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} -\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial x}&=u_x \\ &{Integrating it} \\ \phi &= -u_xx+f(y)+c\\ &= -(u \sin \theta )x+f(y)+c...(i)\\ -\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial y}&=u_y \\ &\text{Integrating it} \\ \phi &= -u_y y+f(x)+c\\ &= -(u \cos \theta )y+f(x)+c...(ii)\\ & \text{By equation (i) and (ii),}\\ \phi &= -u(x \sin \theta+y \cos \theta )\\ &\text{If we take,} \\ \frac{\partial \phi }{\partial x}&= u_x \; and \; \frac{\partial \phi }{\partial y}= u_y\\ \text{then}, \; \phi &= u(x \sin \theta +y \cos \theta )\\ \text{So}, \; \phi &= \pm u(x \sin \theta +y \cos \theta ) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 57 A body floating in a liquid is in a stable state of equilibrium if its
solution: For stability of floating body M lies above G GM [latex]\gt[/latex] 0

options.A: metacentre lies above its centre of gravity
options.B: metacentre lies below its centre of gravity

question:
Question 58 Velocity of flow is proportional to the first power of hydraulic gradient in Darcy's law. The
law is applicable to
solution: Darcy's law is valid for laminar flow condition in porous media.

options.D: laminar as well as turbulent flow in porous media

question: Question 59 Two identical pipes (i.e., having the same length, same diameter, and same roughness) are used to withdraw water from a reservoir. In the first case, they are attached in series and discharge freely into the atmosphere. In the second case, they are attached in parallel and also discharge freely into the atmosphere. Neglecting all minor losses, and assuming that the friction factor is same in both the cases, the ratio of the discharge in the parallel arrangement to that in the series arrangement (round off to 2 decimal places) is ______
solution: Given: Two identical pipes of same length (L), diameter (D) and roughness ([latex]k_s[/latex]). First case (series) Assume height of reservoir = H [latex]\begin{aligned} H &=h_{f1} +h_{f2}\;\;\;...(i)\\ H&=2h_{f1} \;\;\;(\because h_{f1}=h_{f2})\\ H&=2\left ( \frac{8Q_1^2}{\pi^2 g} \times \frac{fL}{D^5} \right ) \end{aligned}[/latex] Second case (Parallel) [latex]H =\frac{8}{\pi^2 g}\left ( \frac{Q_2}{2} \right )^2 \times \frac{fL}{D^5}\;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] By eq. (i) and (ii) [latex]\begin{aligned} 2\left ( \frac{8Q_1^2}{\pi^2 g} \times \frac{fL}{D^5} \right )&=\frac{8}{\pi^2 g}\left ( \frac{Q_2}{2} \right )^2 \times \frac{fL}{D^5}\\ \frac{Q_2}{Q_1}&=\sqrt{8}=2.83 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 60 Consider the reactor shown in the figure. The flow rate through the reactor is [latex]Q \; m^3/h[/latex]. The concentrations (in mg/L) of a compound in the influent and effluent are [latex]C_0[/latex] and C, respectively. The compound is degraded in the reactor following the first order reaction. The mixing condition of the reactor can be varied such that the reactor becomes either a completely mixed flow reactor (CMFR) or a plug-flow reactor (PFR). The length of the reactor can be adjusted in these two mixing conditions to [latex]L_{CMFR}[/latex] and [latex]L_{PFR}[/latex] while keeping the cross-section of the reactor constant. Assuming steady stateand for [latex]C/C_0 =0.8[/latex], the value of [latex]L_{CMFR}/L_{PFR}[/latex] (round off to 2 decimal places) is _______
solution: Hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides are considered primary air pollutants. [latex]c=\frac{c_0}{1+kt}[/latex] For (PFR) plug flow reactor [latex]\begin{aligned} c&=c_0e^{-kt} \\ \text{As}\;\; c/c_0 &=0.8 \\ \text{For CMFR} \;\; 0.8&=\frac{1}{1+kt_{CMFR}} \\ \Rightarrow \;\;t_{CMFR} &=\frac{0.25}{k} \\ \text{For PFR} \;\; 0.8&=e^{-kt_{PFR}} \\ \Rightarrow \;\; t_{PFR}&=\frac{0.22314}{k} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now for steady state [latex]\begin{aligned} v&=\text{constant}\\ L&=vt\\ So, \;\;\frac{L_{CMFR}}{L_{PFR}}&=\frac{vt_{CMFR}}{vt_{PFR}}\\ &=\frac{0.25}{0.22314}=1.12 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 61 The velocity field in a flow system is given by [latex]v=2i+(x+y)j+(xyz)k[/latex]. The acceleration of the fluid at (1,1,2) is
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\vec{v} &=2\hat{i}(x+y)\hat{j}+xyz\hat{k} \\ 
 u&=2 \\ 
 v&=x+y \\ 
 w&=xyz \\ 
 a_x&=u\frac{\partial u}{\partial x} +v\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}+w\frac{\partial u}{\partial z}+\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}=0\\ 
 a_y&=x+y+2 \\ 
 a_z&= u\frac{\partial w}{\partial x} +v\frac{\partial w}{\partial y}+w\frac{\partial w}{\partial z}+\frac{\partial w}{\partial t}\\ 
 &= 2(yz)+(x+y)(xz)+xyz(xy)\\ 
 a_z&=2yz+x^2z+xyz+x^2y^2z \\ 
&At\;(1,1,2) \\ 
a_y&=11+2=4\\
a_z&=2(1)(2)+(1)^2(2)+(1)(1)(2)+(1)^2(1)^2(2)\\
&=4+2+2+2=10\\
\vec{a}&=4\hat{j}+10\hat{k}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 62 A solid sphere of radius, r, and made of material with density, [latex]\rho _s[/latex], is moving through the atmosphere (constant pressure, p)with a velocity, v. The net force ONLY due to atmospheric pressure ([latex]F_p[/latex]) acting on the sphere at any time, t, is
solution:
When object of any shape ( not only sphere) is subjected to uniform pressure over entire surface, the net force is
zero because pressure force at any point is balanced by an equal and opposite force on opposite point.

question: Question 63 Consider a laminar flow in the x-direction between two infinite parallel plates (Couette flow). The lower plate is stationary and the upper plate is moving with a velocity of 1 cm/s in the x-direction. The distance between the plates is 5 mm and the dynamic viscosity of the fluid is 0.01 [latex]N-s/m^2[/latex]. If the shear stress on the lower plate is zero, the pressure gradient, [latex]\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}[/latex], (in [latex]N/m^2[/latex] per m,round off to 1 decimal place)is _______
solution: Given fl\ow is a couette flow with pressure gradient [latex]\mu =0.01N-s/m^2[/latex] h=5mm if [latex]\tau _{y=0}=0, \; \text{find}\; \frac{dp}{dx}[/latex] The velocity distribution, for the couette flow with pressure gradient is given by [latex]u=\frac{wy}{h}-\frac{1}{2\mu }\frac{dp}{dx}[hy-y^2][/latex] where w is the velocity of the top plate and h is the gap between the plates [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{du}{dy}&=\frac{w}{h}-\frac{1}{2\mu }\frac{dp}{dx}[h-2y] \\ \left.\begin{matrix} \frac{du}{dy} \end{matrix}\right|_{y=0} &=\frac{w}{h}-\frac{1}{2\mu }\frac{dp}{dx}h \\ \tau _{y=0}&=\mu \left [ \frac{w}{h}-\frac{1}{2\mu }\frac{dp}{dx}h \right ] \\ \tau _{y=0}&=\frac{w\mu }{h}-\frac{1}{2}\frac{dp}{dx}h \\ \text{when}\; \tau _{y=0}&=0, \; \text{we will have}\\ \frac{1}{2}\frac{dp}{dx}h&=\frac{w\mu }{h}\\ \frac{dp}{dx}&=\frac{2w\mu }{h^2} \\ &=\frac{2 \times 1 \times 10^{-2}\times 0.01}{(5 \times 10^{-3})^2} \\ &=8 N/m^2 \; \text{per} \; m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 64 Two water reservoirs are connected by a siphon (running full) of total length 5000 m and diameter of 0.10m, as shown below The inlet leg length of the siphon to its summit is 2000m. The difference in the water surface levels of the two reservoirs is 5 m. Assume the permissible minimum absolute pressure at the summit of siphon to be 2.5 m of water when running full. Given: friction factor f=0.02 throughout, atmospheric pressure= 10.3 m of water, and acceleration due to gravity g= 9.81 [latex]m/s^2[/latex]. Considering only major loss using Darcy-Weisbach equation, the maximum height of the summit of siphon from the water level of upper reservoir,h (in m, round off to 1 decimal place)is _____
solution: Applying Bernoulli's equation between 1 & 3 [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{P_1}{\rho g}+\frac{v_1^2}{2g}+z_1&= \frac{P_3}{\rho g}+\frac{v_3^2}{2g}+z_3+h_{f13}\\ z_1-z_3&=h_{f13}\;\;\;(\because \; P_1=P_3=P_{atm}\; and \; v_1=v_3=0) \\ 5&=\frac{fLv^2}{2gd} \\ v^2&=\frac{5 \times 2\times 9.81\times 0.1}{0.02\times 5000} \\ v&=0.313m/s \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying Bernoulli's equation between 1 & 2 [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{P_1}{\rho g}+\frac{v_1^2}{2g}+z_1&= \frac{P_2}{\rho g}+\frac{v_2^2}{2g}+z_2+h_{f12}\\ 10.3+0+0&=2.5+\frac{0.313^2}{2 \times 9.81}+h+\frac{0.02 \times 2000 \times 0.313^2}{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.1}\\ h&=5.798m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 A rectangular open channel has a width of 5 m and a bed slope of 0.001. For a uniform flow of depth 2 m, the velocity is 2 m/s. The Manning's roughness coefficient for the channel is
solution: Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} V&= 2 m/sec, \; S=0.001\\ A&=5 \times 2=10m^2\\ P&=5+2+2=9m\\ & \text{Hydraulic mean radius}\\ (R)&=\frac{A}{P}=\frac{10}{9}\\ V&=\frac{1}{n}R^{2/3}S^{1/2}\\ 2&=\frac{1}{n}\left ( \frac{10}{9} \right )^{2/3}(0.001)^{1/2}\\ n&=0.0169\simeq 0.017 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 66 A circular duct carrying water gradually contracts from a diameter of 30 cm to 15 cm. The figure shows the arrangement of differential manometer attached to the duct When the water flows, the differential manometer shows a deflection of 8 cm of mercury (Hg). The values of specific gravity of mercury and water are 13.6 and 1.0, respectively. Consider the acceleration due to gravity, [latex]g=9.81m/s^2[/latex]. Assuming frictionless flow, the flow rate (in [latex]m^3/s[/latex], round off to 3 decimal places) through the duct is ____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q&=\frac{A_1A_2}{\sqrt{A_1^2-A_2^2}}\sqrt{2gh} \\ h&=x\left [ \frac{\rho H_g}{\rho _w}-1 \right ] \\ &=0.08(13.6-1)=1.008m \;\;(A_1=4A_2) \\ Q&=\frac{4A_2 \times A_2}{\sqrt{16A_2^2-A_2^2}}\times \sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 1.008} \\ &= \frac{4}{\sqrt{15}} \times A_2 \times \sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 1.008}\\ &= \frac{4}{\sqrt{15}} \times \frac{\pi}{4}(0.15)^2 \times \sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 1.008} \\ Q&=0.081m^3/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 67 In a rectangular channel, the ratio of the velocity head to the flow depth for critical flow condition, is
solution: For Critical flow [latex]\Rightarrow[/latex] Velocity Head is equal to half of hydraulic depth. [latex]\frac{V^2}{2g}=\frac{D}{2}[/latex] for rectangular channel D = y [latex]\frac{\frac{V^2}{2g}}{y}=\frac{1}{2}[/latex]

question: Question 68 A rough pipe of 0.5 m diameter, 300 m length and roughness height of 0.25 mm, carries water (kinematic viscosity [latex]0.9\times 10^{-6}\: \: m^{2}/s[/latex]) with velocity of 3 m/s. Friction factor (f) for laminar flow is given by [latex]f=64/R_{e}[/latex], and for turbulent flow it is given by [latex]\frac{1}{\sqrt{f}}=2\log_{10}\left ( \frac{r}{k} \right )+1.74[/latex] where, [latex]R_e[/latex] = Reynolds number, r = radius of pipe, k = roughness height and [latex]g=9.81\: \: m/s^{2}[/latex]. The head loss (in m, up to three decimal places) in the pipe due to friction is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} R e &=\frac{\rho \cdot V \cdot D}{\mu}=\frac{V \cdot D}{v}=\frac{3 \times(0.5)}{0.9 \times 10^{-6}} \\ &=1.67 \times 10^{6}\\ \text{Means }R e&>2000 \text{ turbulent flow.}\\ \text{So, }\quad \frac{1}{\sqrt{f}}&=2 \log _{10} \frac{D}{2 k_{s}}+1.74 \\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{f}} &=2 \log _{10} \frac{0.5}{2 \times 0.25 \times 10^{-3}}+1.74 \\ f &=0.01669 \\ h_{f} &=\frac{f \cdot L \cdot V^{2}}{2 g D}=\frac{(0.01669)(300)(3)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.5} \\ &=4.594 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 69 A three-fluid system (immiscible) is connected to a vacuum pump. The specific gravity values of the fluids (S1, S2) are given in the figure. The gauge pressure value (in [latex]kN/m^{2}[/latex], up to two decimal places) of [latex]p_{1}[/latex] is ______
solution: Taking [latex]P_{1}[/latex] is in gauge pressure. [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{A}=& P_{1}+\left(0.88 \times 10^{3}\right) \cdot(9.81)(0.5) \\ &+\left(0.95 \times 10^{3}\right)(9.81)(1) \\ \left(10^{3}\right)(9.81)(0.5)=& P_{1}+\left(0.88 \times 10^{3}\right) \cdot(9.81)(0.5) \\ &+\left(0.95 \times 10^{3}\right)(9.81)(1) \\ P_{1}=&-8.73 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 70 A 5 m wide rectangular channel, the velocity u distribution in the vertical direction y is given by [latex]u=1.25y^{\frac{1}{6}}[/latex]. The distance y is measured from the channel bed. If the flow depth is 2 m, the discharge per unit width of the channel is
solution: Discharge through elementary strip, [latex] d Q=5 d y \times u[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Total discharge, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=\int_{0}^{2}(5 d y)\left(1.25 y^{\sqrt{6}}\right) \\ \Rightarrow Q&=6.25 \int_{0}^{2} y^{1 / 6} d y=6.25 \times\left[\frac{y^{1 / 6+1}}{\frac{1}{6}+1}\right]_{0}^{2}\\ \because \quad Q&=12.026 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Discharge per unit width, [latex] q=\frac{12.026}{5}=2.405 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} / \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 71 For a given discharge in an open channel, there are two depths which have the same specific energy. These two depths are known as
solution: Depth with same specific energy are called Alternate depths of flow. It represents a subcritical depth of flow [latex]\left(Y_{2}\right)[/latex] and a supercritical depth of flow [latex]\left(Y_{1}\right) [/latex]

question: Question 72 In a laboratory, a flow experiment is performed over a hydraulic structure. The measured values of discharge and velocity are 0.05 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s and 0.25 m/s, respectively. If the full scale structure (30 times bigger) is subjected to a discharge of 270 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s, then the time scale (model to full scale) value (up to two decimal places) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Froude Law }(F r)_{m}&=(F r)_{p} \\ \left(\frac{V}{\sqrt{L \mathrm{g}}}\right)_{m} &=\left(\frac{v}{\sqrt{L g}}\right)_{p} \quad\left(g_{m}=g_{p}\right) \\ v_{r} &=\sqrt{L_{r}} \\ \text{or}\quad \frac{L_{r}}{T_{r}} &=\sqrt{L} \\ T_{r} &=\sqrt{L_{r}} \\ T_{r} &=\sqrt{\frac{1}{30}}=0.1826 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 73 Variation of water depth(y) in a gradually varied open channel flow is given by the first order differential equation [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{1-e^{-\frac{10}{3}\ln(y)} }{250-45e^{-3\ln(y)}}[/latex] Given initial condition: y(x=0)=0.8 m. The depth (in m, up to three decimal places) of flow at a downstream section at x = 1 m from one calculation step of Single Step Euler Method is ______

Question 74 A closed tank contains 0.5 m thick layer of mercury (specific gravity = 13.6) at the bottom. A 2.0 m thick layer of water lies above the mercury layer. A 3.0 m thick layer of oil (specific gravity = 0.6) lies above the water layer. The space above the oil layer contains air under pressure. The gauge pressure at the bottom of the tank is 196.2 kN/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. The density of water is 1000 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] and the acceleration due to gravity is 9.81 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex]. The value of pressure in the air space is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &P_{a i t} \text { is in gauge pressure. }\\ &\begin{array}{l} P_{a i r}+\left(0.6 \times 10^{3}\right)(9.81)(3)+\left(10^{3}\right)(9.81)(2) \\ \quad+\left(13.6 \times 10^{3}\right)(9.81)(0.5)=196.2 \times 10^{3} \\ P_{a i r}=92.214 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{array} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 75 A 10 m wide rectangular channel carries a discharge of 20 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] under critical condition. Using g = 9.81 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex], the specific energy (in m, up to two decimal places) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E_{c}&=\frac{3}{2} y_{c} \\ y_{c}&=\left(\frac{q^{2}}{g}\right)^{1 / 3} \\ \text{Hear},\quad q&=\frac{20}{10}=2 \\ \Rightarrow\quad E_{c}&=\frac{3}{2}\left(\frac{2^{2}}{9.81}\right)^{1 / 3}=1.11 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 76 A 1:50 model of a spillway is to be tested in the laboratory. The discharge in the prototype spillway is 1000 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex]. The corresponding discharge (in [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex], up to two decimal places) to be maintained in the model, neglecting variation in acceleration due to gravity, is ______
solution: Froude law is valid [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{r} &=L_{r}^{25} \\ \frac{Q_{m}}{Q_{p}} &=\left(\frac{1}{50}\right)^{25} \\ \frac{Q_{m}}{1000} &=\left(\frac{1}{50}\right)^{25} \\ Q_{m} &=0.0566 \mathrm{m}^{3 / \mathrm{s}} \\ \text{So},\quad Q_{m} & \simeq 0.06 \mathrm{m}^{3 / \mathrm{s}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 77 A flow field is given by [latex]u=y^{2} ,v=-xy,w=0.[/latex] Value of the component of the angular velocity(in radians per unit time,up to two decimal places)at the point (0,-1,1) is_____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \omega_{z} &=\frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{\partial v}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}\right] \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial x}(-x y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial y}(y)^{2}\right] \\ &=\frac{1}{2}[-y-2 y] \\ &=-\frac{3 y}{2} \\ \text { At point } &(0,-1,1) \\ \omega_{z} &=-\frac{3}{2} \times-1=1.50 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Note: Since the density variation is not given continuity equation of incompressible flow can not be applied directly to check the possibility of flow.

question: Question 78 Bernoulli's equation is applicable for

Question 79 Water is pumped at a steady uniform flow rate of 0.01 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] through a horizontal smooth circular pipe of 100 mm diameter. Given that the Reynolds number is 800 and g is 9.81[latex] m/s^{2}[/latex], the head loss (in meters, up to one decimal place) per km length due to friction would be_____
solution: Head loss due to frictions, [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{L}&=\frac{n O^{2}}{12.1 d^{5}}\\ \text{Here. }f&= \text{ friction factor}\\ &=\frac{64}{\text { Re }}=\frac{64}{800}=0.08\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Head loss per metre length [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{h_{L}}{L}&=\frac{fQ^{2}}{12.1d^{5}}=\frac{0.08\times(0.01)^{3}}{12.1\times(1.0)^{5}}\\ \frac{h_{L}}{L}&=\frac{0.8}{12.1} = 0.06611 \text{meter/meter}\\ &=66.11\text{meter/km} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 80 A 1 m wide rectangular channel carries a discharge of 2 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex]. The specific energy-depth diagram is prepared for the channel. It is observed in this diagram that corresponding to a particular specific energy; the subcritical depth is twice the supercritical depth. The subcritical depth (in meters, up to two decimal places) is equal to _____
solution: Let Supercritical depth =Y Subcritical depth =2 Y As the specific energy E remains constant for alternate depths [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad E_{1}&=E_{2} \\ \Rightarrow Y_{1}+\frac{Q^{2}}{2 g B^{2} Y_{1}^{2}}&=Y_{2}+\frac{Q^{2}}{2 g B^{2} Y_{2}^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad Y+\frac{2^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times 1^{2} \times( Y)^{2}}&=2 Y+\frac{2^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times 1 \times(2 Y)^{2}} \\ Y+\frac{0.204}{Y^{2}}&=2Y+\frac{0.051}{Y^{2}}\\ \Rightarrow \quad Y=\frac{0.204-0.051}{Y^{2}}&=Y \\ \Rightarrow \quad Y^{3}&=0.1530 \\ \Rightarrow \quad Y&=0.534 \\ \therefore \quad \text{Subcritical depth} \\ &=0.534 \times 2 \\ &=1.0697 \\ &\simeq 1.07 \mathrm{m} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 81 The figure shows a U-tube having a 5 mmx5 mm square cross-section filled with mercury (specific gravity = 13.6) up to a height of 20 cm in each limb (open to the atmosphere). If 5 [latex]cm^{3}[/latex] of water is added to the right limb, the new height (in cm, up to two decimal places) of mercury in the LEFT limb will be_____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{A} &=P_{B} \\ \left(13.6 \times 10^{3}\right) g \times(2 x) &=\left(10^{3}\right) g(20) \\ x &=\frac{10}{3.6}=0.735 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex] So, the new height (in cm to two decimal place of mercury in the left limb will be [latex] =20+0.74=20.74 \mathrm{cm}[/latex]

question: Question 82 If a centrifugal pump has an impeller speed of N (in rpm), discharge Q (in [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] ) and the total head H (in m), the expression for the specific speed [latex]N_{s}[/latex] of the pump is given by
solution: Specific speed of pump. [latex] N_{\mathrm{s}}=\frac{N \sqrt{Q}}{H^{3 / 4}}=\frac{N Q^{0.5}}{H^{0.75} }[/latex]

question: Question 83 Water flows through a 90[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] bend in a horizontal plane as depicted in the figure. A pressure of 140 kPa is measured at section 1-1. The inlet diameter marked at section 1-1 is [latex]\frac{27}{\sqrt{\pi }}cm[/latex], while the nozzle diameter marked at section 2-2 is [latex]\frac{14}{\sqrt{\pi }}cm[/latex].  Assume the following: (i) Acceleration due to gravity = 10 [latex] m/s^{2} [/latex] (ii) Weights of both the bent pipe segment as well as water are negligible. (iii) Friction across the bend is negligible. The magnitude of the force (in kN, up to two decimal places) that would be required to hold the pipe section is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{1} A_{1} &=F_{x} \\ F_{x} &=\left(140 \times 10^{3}\right)\left[\frac{\pi}{4}\left(\frac{0.27}{\sqrt{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right] \\ &=2551.5 \mathrm{N}\\ F_{y} &=P_{2} A_{2} \\ &=\left(1.013 \times 10^{5}\right)\left[\frac{\pi}{4}\left(\frac{0.14}{\sqrt{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right] \\ &=49637 \mathrm{N} \\ \text { Resultant force } &=\sqrt{F_{x}^{2}+F_{y}^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{(2551.5)^{2}+(49637)^{2}} \\ &=259933 \mathrm{N} \\ &=2.60 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 84 A sluice gate used to control the flow in a horizontal channel of unit width is shown in the figure. It is observed that the depth of flow is 1.0 m upstream of the gate, while the depth is 0.2 m downstream of the gate. Assuming a smooth flow transition across the sluice gate, i.e., without any energy loss, and the acceleration due to gravity as 10 [latex] m/s^{2}[/latex] the discharge (in [latex] m^{3}/ s [/latex], up to two decimal places) passing under the sluice gate is_____
solution: Applying Bernoulli's energy balance equation [latex] \begin{aligned} y_{1}+\frac{Q^{2}}{2 g A_{1}^{2}}&=y_{2}+\frac{Q^{2}}{2 g A_{2}^{2}}\\ \text{Given }\quad y_{1}=1 \mathrm{m}, b&=1 \mathrm{m}, \quad y_{2}=0.2 \\ \Rightarrow 1+\frac{q^{2} \times 1^{2}}{2 g(1 \times 1)^{2}}&=0.2+\frac{q^{2} \times 1^{2}}{2 g \times(0.2 \times 1)^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.8 &=\frac{q^{2}}{2 g}\left(\frac{1}{(0.2)^{2}}-1\right) \\ 0.8 &=\frac{q^{2}}{20} \times 24 \\ q &=0.816 \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 A 1 m wide rectangular channel has a bed slope of 0.0016 and the Manning's roughness coefficient is 0.04. Uniform flow takes place in the channel at a flow depth of 0.5 m. At a particular section, gradually varied flow (GVF) is observed and the flow depth is measured as 0.6 m. The GVF profile at that section is classified as
solution: [latex]Q=\frac{1}{n} \times A \times R^{2 / 3} \times S^{1 / 2}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} A=1 \times 0.5=0.5 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ P=1+(0.5 \times 2)=2 \mathrm{m} \\ Q=\frac{1}{0.04} \times 0.5 \times\left(\frac{0.5}{2}\right)^{2 / 3} \times(0.0016)^{1 / 2} \\ &=0.1984 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ q&=\frac{Q}{1}=0.1984 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} / \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex] For rectangular channel [latex] y_{c}=\left(\frac{q^{2}}{g}\right)^{1 / 3}=\left(\frac{0.1984^{2}}{9.81}\right)^{1 / 3}=0.159 \mathrm{m}[/latex] since, [latex]y_{n}>y_{c}[/latex] (Thus it is Mild Slope)[/latex]

question:

the variables expressed in a consistent set of units. The value of r for the pipe AB is 1 and for the pipe BC is 2. If the discharge supplied at the point A (i.e., 100) is equally divided between the pipes AB and AC, the value of r (up to two decimal places) for the pipe AC should be ____________
solution:
Given [latex]h_{j}=r[/latex] Because of the given condition of equal discharge 
distribution in pipe AB and AC, the discharge in AB 
and AC will be 50 and 50. Now satisfy continuity 
at point B and C, for close Loop ABCA, [latex]

\sum n_{1},&=0\\
\Rightarrow \quad 1(50)^{1.8}+2(20)^{1.5}&=r(50)^{1.5}=0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad 1143.26-430.42&=r(50)^{1.5} \\
r&=0.62

question: Question 88 A penstock of 1 m diameter and 5 km length is used to supply water from a reservoir to an impulse turbine. A nozzle of 15 cm diameter is fixed at the end of the penstock. The elevation difference between the turbine and water level in the reservoir is 500 m. Consider the head loss due to friction as 5% of the velocity head available at the jet. Assume unit weight of water = [latex]10\: kN/m^{3}[/latex] and acceleration due to gravity (g)=[latex]10\: m/s^{2}[/latex]. If the overall efficiency 80%, power generated (expressed in kW and rounded to nearest integer) is ___________
solution: Apply energy equaiton at the free surlace of reservior and exit of nozzle [latex] \begin{aligned} 500&=\text{Head loss } \frac{v_{1}^{2}}{2 g}\\ 500&=0.05 \frac{v_{1}^{2}}{2 g}+\frac{v_{1}^{2}}{2 g}\\ \sqrt{\frac{2 \times 10 \times 500}{1.05}}&=v_{1} \\ V_{1}&=97.59 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec}\\ \text{Water Power WP }\\ &=\frac{1}{2} m v_{1}^{2} \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left(10^{2}\right) \times \frac{\pi}{4}(0.15)^{2}(9759) \\ &=8212178 \mathrm{kW} \\ \text{Now,}\quad \eta_{0}&=\frac{\text { Shaft power }(\$ P)}{W P} \\ 08&=\frac{S P}{8212178} \\ S P&=6569.74 \mathrm{kW} \\ &\simeq 6570 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 89 A 3m wide rectangular channel carries a flow of [latex]6\: m^{3}/s[/latex] . The depth of flow at a section P is 0.5 m. A flat-topped hump is to be placed at the downstream of the section P. Assume negligible energy loss between section P and hump, and consider g as [latex]9.81\: m/s^{2}[/latex] . The maximum height of the hump (expressed in m) which will not change the depth of flow at section P is ____________
solution: The maximum hump [latex](\Delta Z)[/latex] that can be provided is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} y+\frac{Q^{2}}{2 g A^{2}} =&\Delta Z_{\text {hump }}+\frac{3}{2} y_{c} \\ \text{Here}\quad A =&3 \times 0.5=1.5 \mathrm{m}^{2}\\ y_{c}=&\left(\frac{Q^{2}}{g B^{2}}\right)^{1 / 3}=\left(\frac{6^{2}}{9.81 \times 3^{2}}\right)^{1 / 3} \\ =& 0.7415 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow 0.5+\frac{6^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times 1.5^{2}}=\Delta Z_{\text {hump }}+\frac{3}{2} \times 0.7415 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \Delta Z_{\text {hump }}=0.20 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 90 A square plate is suspended vertically from one of its edges using a hinge support as shown in figure. A water jet of 20 mm diameter having a velocity of 10 m/s strikes the plate at its mid-point, at an angle of [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex] with the vertical. Consider g as [latex]9.81\: m/s^{2}[/latex] and neglect the self-weight of the plate. The force F (expressed in N) required to keep the plate in its vertical position is _______________
solution: Force exerted by jet in x direction [latex] \begin{array}{l} F_{x}=m[V \sin \theta-0 \mid \\ =\rho Q \times V \sin \theta \\ =\rho A V \times V \sin \theta \\ =1000 \times \frac{\pi}{4}(0.02)^{2} \times(10)^{2} \sin 30^{\circ} \\ =157079 \mathrm{N} \end{array}[/latex] Taking mornent about hinge [latex] \begin{array}{r} F_{x} \times \frac{0.2}{2}=F \times 02 \\ F=7.85 \mathrm{N} \end{array}[/latex]
