Question 92 A hydraulically efficient trapezoidal channel section has a uniform flow depth of 2m. The bed width (expressed in m) of the channel is __________ .
solution: For hydraulically efficient trapezoidal channel, Lateral side = Horizontal side From figure, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad B \sin 60^{\circ} &=d \\ B &=\frac{d}{\sin 60^{\circ}}=2.31 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 93 A sector gate is provided on a spillway as shown in the figure. Assuming g = [latex]10\: \: m/s^{2}[/latex]  the resultant force per meter length (expressed in kN/m) on the gate will be _______ .
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F_{x} &=\rho g \bar{h} A_{v} \\ &=\left(10^{3}\right)(10)\left(\frac{5}{2}\right)(5 \times 1)\\ &=125 \mathrm{kN}\text{ per unit width}\\ F_{y} &=\rho g \forall \\ \text { where } \forall &=\frac{\pi(5)^{2}}{6}-\left(\frac{1}{2} \times 5 \times 5 \cos 30^{\circ}\right)=2.264 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ F_{y} &=(10)^{3}(10)(2.264)=22.64 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Resultant force per unit width, [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{R}&=\sqrt{F_{x}^{2}+F_{y}^{2}}\\ &=\sqrt{125^{2}+22.64^{2}}=127.03 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 94 A 4 m wide rectangular channel, having bed slope of 0.001 carries a discharge of [latex]16\:\, m^{3}/s[/latex].  Considering Manning's roughness coefficient = 0.012 and [latex]g =10\: \: m/s^{2}[/latex], the category of the channel slope is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=\frac{1}{n} A R^{2 / 3} S^{1 / 2} \\ & A=B y \\ & A=\frac{B y}{B+2 y} \\ & 16=\\ \frac{1}{0.012}\times By&\times \left(\frac{By}{B+2y} \right )^{2/3}\times(0.001)^{1/2}\\ 6.07 &=4 \times \frac{y^{5 / 3}}{(4+2 y)^{2 / 3}} \\ & 1.5178=\frac{y^{5 / 3}}{(4+2 y)^{2 / 3}}\\ y &=\left[1.5178 \times(4 \times 2 y)^{2 / 3}\right]^{3 / 5} \\ &=3.3 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Critical depth } y_{c} &=\left(\frac{q^{2}}{g}\right)^{1 / 3}=\left(\frac{4^{2}}{10}\right)^{1 / 3}=1.169 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] y>y_{c} \Rightarrow [/latex] Flow is subcritical. Hence channel slope is mild.

question: Question 95 The pre-jump Froude Number for a particular flow in a horizontal rectangular channel is 10. The ratio of sequent depths (i.e., post-jump depth to pre-jump depth) is ___________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{y_{2}}{y_{1}} &=\frac{1}{2}\left[-1+\sqrt{1+8 F_{1}^{2}}\right] \\ &=\frac{1}{2}[-1+\sqrt{1+8 \times 100}] \\ \frac{y_{2}}{y_{1}} &=13.65 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 96 A pipe of 0.7 m diameter has a length of 6 km and connects two reservoirs A and B. The water level in reservoir A is at an elevation 30 m above the water level in reservoir B. Halfway along the pipe line, there is a branch through which water can be supplied to a third reservoir C. The friction factor of the pipe is 0.024. The quantity of water discharged into reservoir C is 0.15 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s. Considering the acceleration due to gravity as 9.81 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex] and neglecting minor losses, the discharge (in [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex]) into the reservoir B is __________.

Question 97 The velocity components of a two dimensional plane motion of a fluid are: [latex]u=\frac{y^{3}}{3}+2x-x^{2}y[/latex] and [latex]v=xy^{2}-2y-\frac{x^{3}}{3}[/latex]. The correct statement is:
solution:
Continuity equation [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial v}{\partial y} &=0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad(2-2 x y)+(2 x y-2) &=0 \\
0 &=0
\end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, incompressible fluid. [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{z} &=\frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{\partial v}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}\right] \\
&=\frac{1}{2}\left[y^{2}-\frac{3 x^{2}}{3}-\left(\frac{3 y^{2}}{3}-x^{2}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{1}{2}\left[y^{2}-x^{2}-y^{2}+x^{2}\right] \\
&=0
\end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, flow is irrotational.

options.A: Fluid is incompressible and flow is irrotational
options.B: Fluid is incompressible and flow is rotational
options.C: Fluid is compressible and flow is irrotational
options.D: Fluid is compressible and flow is rotational

question: Question 98 A triangular gate with a base width of 2 m and a height of 1.5 m lies in a vertical plane. The top vertex of the gate is 1.5 m below the surface of a tank which contains oil of specific gravity 0.8. Considering the density of water and acceleration due to gravity to be 1000 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] and 9.81 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex], respectively, the hydrostatic force (in kN) exerted by the oil on the gate is__________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \bar{h} &=1.5+1.5\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)=2.5 \mathrm{m} \\ F_{R} &=\rho g \bar{h} A \\ &=(800)(9.81)(2.5)\left(\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 1.5\right) \\ &=29430 \mathrm{N}=29.43 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 99 A hydraulic jump takes place in a frictionless rectangular channel. The pre-jump depth is [latex]y_{p}[/latex]. The alternate and sequent depths corresponding toalternate and sequent depths corresponding to [latex]y_{p}[/latex] are [latex]y_{a}[/latex] and [latex]y_{s}[/latex] respectively. The correct relationship among [latex]y_{p},y_{a}[/latex] and [latex]y_{s}[/latex] is:

Question 100 A nozzle is so shaped that the average flow velocity changes linearly from 1.5 m/s at the beginning to 15 m/s at its end in a distance of 0.375 m. The magnitude of the convective acceleration (in m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex]) at the end of the nozzle is _________.
solution:
Convective acceleration [latex]=\frac{u \partial u}{\partial x} [/latex] [latex]
 =15 \times \frac{15-1.5}{0.375}=540 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} [/latex]

question: Question 101 The relationship between the length scale ratio [latex](L_{r})[/latex] and the velocity scale ratio [latex](V_{r})[/latex]  in hydraulic models, in which Froude dynamic similarity is maintained, is:
solution: As per Froude Law [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(\frac{V}{\sqrt{L g}}\right)_{m}&=\left(\frac{V}{\sqrt{L g}}\right)_{p} \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{r}&=\sqrt{L_{r}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 102 The drag force [latex]F_{D}[/latex], on a sphere kept in a uniform flow field depends on the diameter of the sphere, D; flow velocity, V; fluid density, [latex]\rho[/latex]; and dynamic viscosity, [latex]\mu[/latex]. Which of the following options represents the non-dimensional parameters which could be used to analyze this problem?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{For sphere,}\quad A&=\frac{\pi}{4} D^{2} \\ F_{D} &=C_{D} \times \frac{1}{2} \times p \times A \times V^{2} \\ F_{D} &=C_{D} \times \frac{1}{2} \times \rho \times\left(\frac{\pi}{4} D^{2}\right) \times V^{2} \\ \frac{F_{D}}{\rho D^{2} V^{2}} &=\frac{1}{2} \times\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \times C_{D} \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, right hand side is dimensionless, so [latex] \frac{F_{0}}{\rho D^{2} V^{2}}[/latex] should also be a dimensionless parameter. Option (C) [latex]\frac{F_{0}}{\rho V^{2} D^{2}}, \frac{\rho V D}{\mu}[/latex]

question: Question 103 A short reach of a 2 m wide rectangular open channel has its bed level rising in the direction of flow at a slope of 1 in 10000. It carries a discharge of 4 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] and its Manning's roughness coefficient is 0.01. The flow in this reach is gradually varying. At a certain section in this reach, the depth of flow was measured as 0.5 m. The rate of change of the water depth with distance, dy/dx, at this section is ____ (use g = 10 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex]).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Adverb slope }&= -\frac{1}{1000}\\\\ Q &=4 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ n &=0.01 \\ y &=0.5 \mathrm{m} \\ \frac{d y}{d x} &=\frac{S_{0}-S_{f}}{1-F_{t}^{2}} \\ F_{r} &=\frac{V}{\sqrt{g y}}=\frac{Q}{2 y \sqrt{g y}} \\ &=\frac{4}{2 \times 0.5 \sqrt{10 \times 0.5}}=1.789 \\ R &=\frac{A}{P}=\frac{2 \times 0.5}{2+2 \times 0.5}=\frac{1}{3} \\ Q &=\frac{1}{n} A R^{2 / 3} S_{f}^{1 / 2} \end{aligned}[/latex] On solving for [latex]S_{f} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{f}^{1 / 2} &=6.923 \times 10^{-3} \\ \frac{d y}{d x} &=\frac{-\frac{1}{10000}-6.923 \times 10^{-3}}{1-(1.789)^{2}} \\ &=3.191 \times 10^{-3} \simeq 0.0032 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 104 A hydraulic jump is formed in a 2 m wide rectangular channel which is horizontal and frictionless. The post-jump depth and velocity are 0.8 m and 1 [latex]m/s[/latex], respectively. The pre-jump velocity is _______[latex]m/s[/latex] (use g=10 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex]).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y_{2} &=0.8 \mathrm{m} \\ v_{2} &=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ F_{f_{2}} &=\frac{v_{2}}{\sqrt{g D}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{10 \times \frac{0.8 \times 2}{2}}} \\ F_{f_{2}} &=0.3535 \\ y_{1} &=\frac{y_{2}}{2}\left(-1+\sqrt{1+8 F_{12}^{2}}\right) \\ &=\frac{0.8}{2}\left(-1+\sqrt{1+8 \times 0.3535^{2}}\right) \\ &=0.165643 \\ \Rightarrow \quad v_{1} y_{1} &=v_{2} y_{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad v_{1} &=\frac{1 \times 0.8}{0.165643}=4.83 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 105 Two reservoirs are connected through a 930 m long, 0.3 m diameter pipe, which has a gate valve. The pipe entrance is sharp (loss coefficient = 0.5) and the valve is half-open (loss coefficient = 5.5). The head difference between the two reservoirs is 20 m. Assume the friction factor for the pipe as 0.03 and g = 10 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex]. The discharge in the pipe accounting for all minor and major losses is _________ [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] .
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L&=930 \mathrm{m} \\ D&= 0.3 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Apply energy equation between A and B [latex] \begin{aligned} 20&=\frac{0.5 V^{2}}{2 g}+\frac{(0.03)(930) V^{2}}{2 g(0.3)}+\frac{5.5 V^{2}}{2 g}+\frac{V^{2}}{20} \\\ 20&=\frac{(0.03)(930)}{(03)} \frac{v^{2}}{20}+\frac{70 v^{2}}{20} \\ 20&=\frac{100 v^{2}}{2 g} \\ V&=2 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{se} \\ a&=\frac{\pi}{4}(0.3)^{2}(2) \\ Q&=0.1414 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 106 A circular pipe has a diameter of 1m, bed slope of 1 in 1000, and Manning's roughness coefficient equal to 0.01. It may be treated as an open channel flow when it is flowing just full, i.e., the water level just touches the crest. The discharge in this condition is denoted by [latex]Q_{full}[/latex]. Similarly, the discharge when the pipe is flowing half-full i.e., with a flow depth of 0.5m, is denoted by [latex]Q_{half}[/latex]. The ratio [latex]Q_{full}/Q_{half}[/latex] is:
solution: Given diamator, d=1m. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{slope,} \quad S&=\frac{1}{1000} \\ n&=0.01\\ \frac{Q_{full}}{Q_{half}} &= \frac{\left[\frac{A}{N}(R)^{2/3}S^{1/2} \right]_{\text{full}}}{\left[\frac{A}{N}(R)^{2/3}S^{1/2} \right]_{\text{half}}}\\ &=\frac{\left[AR^{2/3} \right ]_{\text{full}}}{\left[AR^{2/3} \right ]_{\text{half}}}\\ R_{\text{full}}&=R_{\text{Half}}=\frac{d}{4}\\ &=\frac{\frac{\pi d^{2}}{4}}{\frac{\pi d^{2}}{8}}=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 107 For steady incompressible flow through a closed- conduit of uniform cross-section, the direction of flow will always be :
solution:
In closed uniform conduit, velocity head remains 
Constant, thus flow will be from higher to lower 
Piezometric head, Piezometrie head [latex]=\frac{P}{\gamma}+z [/latex]

options.D: From higher to lower piezometric head

question: Question 108 In a two-dimensional steady flow field, in a certain region of the x-y plane, the velocity component in the x-direction is given by [latex]v_{x}=x^{2}[/latex] and the density varies as [latex]\rho =\frac{1}{x}[/latex]. Which of the following is a valid expression for the velocity component in the y- direction, [latex]v_{y}[/latex] ?
solution: Continuity equation in steady flow. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial(\rho u)}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial(\rho v)}{\partial y} &=0 \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left[\frac{1}{x} \cdot x^{2}\right]+\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(\frac{1}{x} \cdot v_{y}\right) &=0 \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x}(x)+\frac{1}{x} \frac{\partial v_{y}}{x \partial y} &=0 \\ 1+\frac{1}{x} \frac{\partial v_{y}}{\partial y} &=0 \\ -x &=\frac{\partial v_{y}}{\partial y} \end{aligned}[/latex] On integrating both sides [latex] v_{y}=-x y[/latex]

question: Question 109 With reference to a standard Cartesian (x,y) plane, the parabolic velocity distribution profile of fully developed laminar flow in x-direction between two parallel, stationary and identical plates that are separated by distance, h, is given by the expression [latex]u=-\frac{h^{2}}{8\mu }\frac{\mathrm{d} p}{\mathrm{d} x}\left [ 1-4(\frac{y}{h})^{2} \right ][/latex] In this equation, the y=0 axis lies equidistant between the plates at a distance h/2 from the two plates, p is the pressure variable and [latex]\mu[/latex] is the dynamic viscosity term. The maximum and average velocities are, respectively
solution: Velocily expression for a laminar flow between two parallel plates is [latex] U=-\frac{n^{2}}{8 u}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\left[1-4\left(\frac{y}{n}\right)^{2}\right][/latex] End condition [latex] U=U_{max}\text{ at }y=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow U_{max} = -\frac{h^{2}}{8\mu}\left(\frac{dp}{dx} \right )[/latex] Discharges dQ = Area x Velocily [latex] \Rightarrow \Delta 0=\left[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{8 \mu}\left(\frac{d \rho}{d x}\right)\left(1-4\left(\frac{y}{n}\right)^{2}\right)\right](d y \times 1)[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &\Rightarrow Q=-\frac{h^{2}}{8 \mu}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right) \int_{-h / 2}^{h / 2}\left(1-\frac{4 y^{2}}{h^{2}}\right) d y\\ &=-\frac{h^{2}}{8 \mu}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\left[y-\frac{4 y^{3}}{3 h^{2}}\right]_{-n / 2}^{h / 2}\\ &=-\frac{h^{2}}{8 \mu}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\left[\left\{\frac{h}{2}-\left(-\frac{h}{2}\right)\right\}-\left\{\frac{4}{3 h^{2}}\left(\frac{h^{3}}{8}-\left(-\frac{h^{3}}{8}\right)\right)\right\}\right]\\ &=-\frac{h^{3}}{12 \mu}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\\ &Q=A V\\ &-\frac{h^{3}}{12 \mu}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)=(h \times 1) \times U_{a v g}\\ &\Rightarrow \quad U_{a v g}=-\frac{h^{2}}{12 \mu}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 110 A rectangular channel of 2.5 m width is carrying a discharge of 4 [latex]m^3[/latex]/s. Considering that acceleration due to gravity as 9.81 m/[latex]s^2[/latex], the velocity of flow (in m/s) corresponding to the critical depth (at which the specific energy is minimum) is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=4 m^{3} / s, B=2.5 m \\ \Rightarrow \quad q &=\frac{4}{2.5} m^{3} / s / m \\ &=1.6 m^{3} / s / m \\ y_{c}^{3} &=\frac{q^{2}}{g} \Rightarrow y_{c}=0.639 m \end{aligned} [/latex] At critical depth velocity head [latex]=\frac{y_{c}}{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad \frac{V^{2}}{2 g}&=\frac{0.639}{2}\\ \Rightarrow V&=\sqrt{0.639 \times 9} \\ &=2.504 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 111 A venturimeter having a throat diameter of 0.1 m is used to estimate the flow rate of a horizontal pipe having a diameter of 0.2 m. For an observed pressure difference of 2 m of water head and coefficient of discharge equal to unity, assuming that the energy losses are negligible, the flow rate (in [latex]m^3[/latex]/s) through the pipe is approximately equal to
solution: Diameter of throat, [latex] d=0.1 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Diameter of pipe, [latex] D=0.2 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Pressure difference, [latex] \frac{P_{1}-P_{2}}{w}=2 m=h[/latex] Coefficient of discharge [latex] C_{D}=1[/latex] Discharge, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=\frac{C_{D} A_{1} A_{2} \sqrt{2 g h}}{\sqrt{A_{1}^{2}-A_{2}^{2}}}\\ A_{1} &=\frac{\pi}{4}(0.2)^{2} \\ \text { and } A_{2} &=\frac{\pi}{4}(0.1)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad Q &=\frac{1 \times\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right)^{2} \times(0.2)^{2}(0.1)^{2} \sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 2}}{\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \sqrt{(0.2)^{4}-(0.1)^{4}}} \\ &=0.0508=0.050 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 112 A horizontal nozzle of 30 mm diameter discharges a steady jet of water into the atmosphere at a rate of 15 liters per second. The diameter of inlet to the nozzle is 100 mm. The jet Impinges normal to a flat stationary plate held close to the nozzle end. Neglecting air friction and considering the density of water as 1000 kg/[latex]m^3[/latex], force exerted by the jet (in N) on the plate is _______
solution: [latex]\text{Force }=\rho a V^{2} [/latex] [latex] \mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{a} \mathrm{V}=15 \; litre/sec (given)[/latex] [latex] \text{Force }=\rho \frac{\mathrm{Q}^{2}}{\mathrm{a}} [/latex] [latex] =1000 \times \frac{15^{2}}{\pi} \times 30^{2} \mathrm{m}^{3} \times 10^{-6} \frac{\mathrm{m}^{6}}{\mathrm{s}^{2}} \times \frac{1}{10^{-6}} \mathrm{m}^{2} [/latex] [latex] =1000 \times \frac{1}{\pi} \mathrm{N}=318.3 \mathrm{N}[/latex]

question: Question 113 Group I lists a few devices while Group II provides information about their uses. Match the devices with their corresponding use.

Question 114 A plane flow has velocity components [latex]u=\frac{x}{T_{1}}, \; v=-\frac{y}{T_{2}}[/latex] and w=0 along x, y and z directions respectively, where[latex]T_{1}(\neq 0)[/latex] and [latex]T_{2}(\neq 0)[/latex] are constants having the dimensions of time. The given flow is incompressible if
solution: For a flow to exist [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial v}{\partial y}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{T_{1}}-\frac{1}{T_{2}}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad T_{1}&=T_{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 115 A straight 100 m long raw water gravity main is to carry water from an intake structure to the jack well of a water treatment plant. The required flow through this water main is [latex]0.21 m^{3}/s[/latex]. Allowable velocity through the main is 0.75 m/s. Assume f = 0.01, g=9.81[latex]m/s^{2}[/latex]. The minimum gradient (in cm/100 m length) to be given to this gravity main so that the required amount of water flows without any difficulty is ___________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q&=0.21 \mathrm{m}^{1} / \mathrm{s}\\ \text{Allowable velocily} &=0.75 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ f&=0.01\\ g&=9.81m/s^{2}\\ \frac{\pi d^{2}}{4} &=\frac{0}{v}=\frac{0.21}{0.75}=0.28 m^{2} \\ \Rightarrow\quad d &=0.597 m \\ \Rightarrow\quad \frac{ft V^{2}}{2 g d} &=n_{1}=\frac{0.01 \times 100 \times(0.75)^{2}}{2 \times 981 \times 0.597} m \\ &=4.8 \mathrm{cm} \\ &=0.048 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow\quad[/latex] Minimum gradient [latex]=\frac{h_{f}}{l}=\frac{4.8cm}{100m}[/latex] Hence, answor is 4.8

question: Question 118 A rectangular channel having a bed slope of 0.0001, width 3.0 m and Manning's coefficient 'n' 0.015, carries a discharge of 1.0 [latex]m^3/s[/latex]. Given that the normal depth of flow ranges between 0.76 m and 0.8 m. The minimum width of a throat (in m) that is possible at a given section, while ensuring that the prevailing normal depth is not exceeded along the reach upstream of the contraction, is approximately equal to (assume negligible losses)
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} n=0.015 \\ Q=1 m^{3} / s \end{array}[/latex] Normal depth of flow between 0.76m to 0.8m. If prevailing normal depth of flow is not exceeded, there must not be chocking of the section or there must be just chocking. Thus the width of the section should be such that for the prevailing specific energy there should be critical flow at the contracted section i.e. [latex] \frac{3}{2}\left(\frac{q^{2}}{g}\right)^{1 / 3}=E_{C}=E_{\text {intia }} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad \frac{3}{2}\left[\frac{\left(\frac{Q}{B_{\min }}\right)^{2}}{g}\right]^{1 / 3}=E_{\text {initie }}[/latex] Let us now calculate [latex]E_{\text {inital }} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=\frac{1}{2} A R^{2 / 3} S_{0}^{1 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1&= \frac{1}{0.015}(3 y)\left(\frac{3 y}{3+2 y}\right)^{2 / 3}(0.0001)^{1 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad y&=0.78 m \\ \Rightarrow \quad E_{\text {initial }}&=y+\frac{q^{2}}{2 g y^{2}} \\ &=0.78+\frac{\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times(0.78)^{2}} \\ &=0.7893 \mathrm{m} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{3}{2}\left[\frac{\left(\frac{Q}{B_{\min }}\right)^{2}}{g}\right]^{1 / 3}&=0.7893 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{3}{2} \frac{(1)^{2 / 3}}{g^{1 / 3}\left(B_{\min }\right)^{2 / 3}}&=0.7893 \\ \mathrm{B}_{\mathrm{min}}&=0.836 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 119 A venturimeter, having a diameter of 7.5 cm at the throat and 15 cm at the enlarged end, is installed in a horizontal pipeline of 15 cm diameter. The pipe carries an incompressible fluid at a steady rate of 30 litres per second. The difference of pressure head measured in terms of the moving fluid in between the enlarged and the throat of the venturimeter is observed to be 2.45 m. Taking the acceleration due to gravity as 9.81 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex], the coefficient of discharge of the venturimeter (correct up to two places of decimal) is___
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=30 \; l / \mathrm{s} \\ \left(\frac{P_{1}}{w}+Z_{1}\right)&-\left(\frac{P_{2}}{w}+Z_{2}\right) =2.45 \mathrm{m}=h \\ g&=9.81 \\ Q&=C_{d} \frac{A_{1} A_{2}}{\sqrt{A_{1}^{2}-A_{2}^{2}}} \sqrt{2 g h} \\ C_{d} &=\frac{Q_{1} A_{2}}{\sqrt{A_{1}^{2}-A_{2}^{2}} \sqrt{2 g h}}\\ &= \frac{30 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}}{\frac{\frac{\pi}{4}(0.15)^{2} \times(0.075)^{2} }{\sqrt{(0.15)^{2}-(0.075)^{2}}}\times \sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 2.45}} \\ C_{\mathrm{d}}&=0.95 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 120 A horizontal jet of water with its cross-sectional area of 0.0028 [latex]m^2[/latex] hits a fixed vertical plate with a velocity of 5 m/s. After impact the jet splits symmetrically in a plane parallel to the plane of the plate. The force of impact (in N) of the jet on the plate is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Force on plate } &=\left(\rho_{w} a V\right) \mathrm{V} \\ &=\rho_{w} a V^{2} \\ &=1000 \times 0.0028 \times(5)^{2} \\ &=70 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 121 A particle moves along a curve whose parametric equations are: [latex]x=t^{3}+2t[/latex], [latex]y=-3e^{-2t}[/latex]  and [latex]z=2 \sin (5t)[/latex] , where x, y and z show variations of the distance covered by the particle (in cm)with time t (in s). The magnitude of the acceleration of the particle (in [latex] cm/s^{2}[/latex]) at t = 0 is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x &=t^{3}+2 t \\ y &=-3 e^{-2 t} \\ z &=2 \sin (5 t) \\ \frac{d x}{d t} &=3 e^{2}+2 \\ \Rightarrow\quad a_{x} &=\frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=6 t \\ \frac{d y}{d t} &=-3 e^{-2} \times(-2)=6 e^{-2 t} \\ \Rightarrow\quad a_{y} &=\frac{d^{2} y}{d t^{3}}=-12 e^{-2 t}\\ \Rightarrow\quad \frac{d z}{d t} &=2 \times 5 \cos (5 t) \\ &=10 \cos (5 t) \\ \Rightarrow\quad a_{z} &=\frac{d^{2} z}{d t^{2}}=-50 \sin 5 t \\ \vec{a} &=a_{x} \hat{i}+a_{y} \hat{j}+a_{z} \hat{k} \\ \vec{a} \text { at } t=0 &=0 \hat{i}-12 \hat{j}+0 \hat{k} \\ \vec{a} &=-12 \hat{j} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow\quad[/latex] Magnitude of acceleration at t=0 [latex] =12 \mathrm{cm} / \mathrm{s}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 122 The dimension for kinematic viscosity is
solution: The Sl unit of kinematic viscosity is [latex]\mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] Dimension of kinematic viscosity [latex] [\mathrm{v}]=\mathrm{L}^{2} / \mathrm{T} [/latex]

question: Question 123 An incompressible homogeneous fluid is flowing steadily in a variable diameter pipe having the large and small diameters as 15 cm and 5 cm, respectively. If the velocity at a section at the 15 cm diameter portion of the pipe is 2.5 m/s, the velocity of the fluid (in m/s) at a section falling in 5 cm portion of the pipe is________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\pi}{4}(15)^{2} \times 25 &=\frac{\pi}{4}(5)^{2} \times v \\ \Rightarrow &=2.5 \times 9=22.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 124 The normal depth in a wide rectangular channel is increased by 10%. The percentage increase in
the discharge in the channel is:
solution: The discharge in the channel is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=\frac{1}{n} A R^{2 / 3} S^{1 / 2}\\ \Rightarrow \quad Q&=\frac{1}{n}(B y)\left(\frac{B y}{B+2 y}\right)^{2 / 3} S^{1 / 2} \end{aligned}[/latex] For a wide rectangular channel [latex] \begin{aligned} B &\gg y \\ \therefore\quad Q&=\frac{1}{n}(B y)(y)^{2 / 3} S^{1 / 2} \\ \therefore\quad Q &\propto y^{5 / 3} \\ \text{let} Q_{1}&=k(y)^{5 / 3} \\ \therefore\quad Q_{2}&=k(1.1 y)^{5 / 3} \\ \therefore\quad \frac{Q_{2}-Q_{1}}{Q_{1}} \times 100&=\frac{(1.1 \mathrm{y})^{5 / 3}-(\mathrm{y})^{5 / 3}}{(\mathrm{y})^{5 / 3}} \times 100 \\ &= 17.21 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 125 A 2 km long pipe of 0.2 m diameter connects two reservoirs. The difference between water levels
in the reservoirs is 8 m. The Darcy-Weisbachfriction factor of the pipe is 0.04. Accounting for
frictional, entry and exit losses, the velocity in the pipe (in m/s) is:
solution: Frictional loss, [latex] n_{1}=\frac{1 L V^{2}}{d \times 20}[/latex] Loss of head at entrance, [latex] h_{L}=\frac{0.5 V^{2}}{2 g}[/latex] Loss at exit of pipe. [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{c}&=\frac{V^{2}}{2g}\\ \therefore 8 &= \frac{fLV^{2}}{d\times }+\frac{0.5V^{2}}{2g}+\frac{V^{2}}{2g}\\ \Rightarrow \quad 8 &= \frac{0.04\times 2000\times V^{2}}{2\times g\times 0.2}+\frac{V^{2}}{2g}+\frac{0.5V^{2}}{2g}\\ \Rightarrow\quad 8&=20.3873V^{2}+0.07645V^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad V&=0.625 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ &= 0.63 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 126 For a two dimensional flow field, the stream function [latex]\Psi[/latex] is given as [latex]\Psi =\frac{3}{2}(y^{2}-x^{2})[/latex]. The magnitude of discharge occurring between the stream lines passing through points (0,3) and (3,4) is:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} a &=\Psi_{1}-\Psi_{2} \\ &=\frac{3}{2}(9-0)-\frac{3}{2}(16-9) \\ &=\frac{27}{2}-24+\frac{27}{2}=3 \text { units } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 129 The circular water pipes shown in the sketch are flowing full. The velocity of flow (in m/s) in the
branch pipe "R" is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_{1}&=Q_{2}+Q_{3}\\ A_{1}V_{1}&=A_{2}V_{2}+A_{3}V_{3}\\ \Rightarrow \frac{\pi}{4}(4)^{2} \times 6&=\frac{\pi}{4}(4)^{2} \times 5+\frac{\pi}{4}(2)^{2} \times V_{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 16 \times 6&=16 \times 5+4 \mathrm{V}_{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 16&=4 \mathrm{V}_{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{3}&=4 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \therefore \qquad V&=4 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 130 A rectangular open channel of width 5.0 m is carrying a discharge of 100 [latex]m^3[/latex]/s. The Froude number
of the flow is 0.8. The depth of flow (in m) in the channel is
solution: Froude Number [latex] \begin{aligned} F&=\frac{V}{\sqrt{g y}} \\ \Rightarrow 0.8&=\frac{V}{\sqrt{9.81 \mathrm{y}}} &\ldots(i)\\ \because \quad Q&=A V \\ \Rightarrow \quad 100&=(5 \mathrm{y}) \mathrm{V} \\ \Rightarrow \quad v&=\frac{100}{5 y}=\frac{20}{y} \\ \therefore \text{From eq. (i)}\\ 0.8&=\frac{20}{\sqrt{9.81} \cdot(y)^{3 / 2}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad y^{3 / 2}&=\frac{20}{0.8 \sqrt{9.81}} \\ \therefore \quad y&=3.99 \simeq 4 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 131 A trapezoidal channel is 10.0 m wide at the base and has a side slope of 4 horizontal to 3 vertical.
The bed slope is 0.002. The channel is lined with smooth concrete (Manning's n = 0.012). The
hydraulic radius (in m) for a depth of flow of 3.0 m is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \because \quad A &=(B+n y) y=\left(10+\frac{4}{3} \times 3\right) \times 3 \\ &=(10+4) 3=42 m^{2} \\ P &=B+2 y \sqrt{n^{2}+1} \\ &=10+6 \sqrt{(4 / 3)^{2}+1} \\ &=10+6 \times \frac{5}{3}=20 m \\ \therefore \quad R &=\frac{A}{P}=\frac{42}{20}=2.1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 132 A spillway discharges flood flow at a rate of 9 [latex]m^3[/latex]/s per metre width. If the depth
of flow on the horizontal apron at the toe of the spillway is 46 cm, the tail water
depth needed to form a hydraulic jump is approximately given by which of the
following options?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{q}&=9 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} / \mathrm{m}\\ \text{and }y_{1}&=46 \mathrm{cm}=0.46 \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore \quad V_{1}&=\frac{q}{y_{1}}=\frac{9}{0.46}=19.565 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ F_{1}&=\frac{V_{1}}{\sqrt{g y_{1}}}=\frac{19.565}{\sqrt{9.81 \times 0.46}}=9.21 \end{aligned}[/latex] Thus, flow is super -critical. Thus the sequent depth will be [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{y_{2}}{y_{1}}&=\frac{1}{2}\left[-1+\sqrt{1+8 F_{1}^{2}}\right]\\ \Rightarrow \quad y_{2}&=\frac{0.46}{2}\left[-1+\sqrt{1+8 \times(9.21)^{2}}\right] \\ \Rightarrow \quad y_{2}&=0.23 \times 25.07 \\ \Rightarrow \quad y_{2}&=5.77 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 133 A single pipe of length 1500 m and diameter 60 cm connects two reservoirs having
a difference of 20 m in their water levels. The pipe is to be replaced by two pipes
of the same length and equal diameter d to convey 25% more discharge under the
same head loss. If the friction factor is assumed to be the same for all the pipes,
the value of d is approximately equal to which of the following options?
solution: For single pipe [latex] \begin{array}{r} n=\frac{81 L Q}{\pi^{2} g D^{2}} \\ L=1500 \mathrm{m}, \mathrm{D}=0.6 \mathrm{m} \\ n_{f}=20 \mathrm{m} \\ Q_{1}=\frac{0.112}{\sqrt{1}} \end{array}[/latex] In case of double pipe discharge is increased by 25% than that of previous case hence. [latex] \begin{aligned} 2Q_{2}&=1.25Q_{1}\\ 20 &= \frac{8F\times 500\times(0.625Q_{1})^{2}}{9.81\times \pi^{2}\times d^{5}}\\ Q_{1}&= \frac{0.402\times d^{5/2}}{\sqrt{f}}\\ \frac{Q_{1}^{2}}{d^{5}}&=0.413\\ Q_{1}^{2}&=\frac{0.413d^{5}}{f}\\ Q_{1}&=\frac{0.642d^{5/2}}{\sqrt{f}}\ldots\\ \text{From eq }(i) &\text{and }(ii),\text{ we get}\\ d&=437 \mathrm{cm}=50 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 134 The flow in a horizontal, frictionless rectangular open channel is supercritical. A
smooth hump is built on the channel floor. As the height of hump is increased,
choked condition is attained. With further increase in the height of the hump, the
water surface will
solution:
The height of the hump attains its maximum value at the chocked condition. Increasing the height of hump after chocked condition results in
nydraulic jump formation in case of super critical fiow. Thus height of water surface will drastical changes upstream and downstream of hump.

options.A: rise at a section upstream of the hump
options.B: drop at a section upstream of the hump

question:
Question 135 For a body completely submerged in a fluid, the centre of gravity (G) and centre
of Buoyancy (O) are known. The body is considered to be in stable equilibrium if
solution: A completely submerged body will be in stable equilibrium when CG lies below the centre of buoyancy. It will be in unstable equilibrium when CG lies above the centre of buoyancy And when the CG coincides with the centre of buoyancy. The body will be in neutral equilibrium

options.A: O does not coincide with the centre of mass of the displaced fluid
options.B: G coincides with the centre of mass of the displaced fluid

question: Question 136 For a given discharge, the critical flow depth in an open channel depends on
solution:
It may be noted that the critical flow condition is
governed solely by the channel geometry and discharge. Other channel properties such as bed slope and roughness do not influence the critical flow condition for any given discharge.

options.C: channel geometry, bed slope and roughness
options.D: channel geometry, bed slope, roughness and Reynolds number

question:
Question 137 The Froude number of flow in a rectangular channel is 0.8. If te depth of flow is
1.5m, the critical depth is
solution: Froude Number for a rectangular channel is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} F &=\frac{V}{\sqrt{g y}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad V &=0.8 \times \sqrt{9.81 \times 1.5} \\ &=3.07 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Discharge per unit width of rectangular channel is given by [latex] q=V y=3.07 \times 1.5=4.6 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} / \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Critical depth, [latex] y_{c}=\left(\frac{q^{2}}{g}\right)^{1 / 3}=\left(\frac{4.6^{2}}{9.81}\right)^{1 / 3}=1.29 m[/latex]

question:
Question 138 For a rectangular channel seetion, Group I lists geometrical elements and Group
II gives proportions for hydraulically efficient section [latex]y_e[/latex] is the flow depth corresponding to hydraulically efficient section. The correct
match of Group I with Group II is
solution: Let the width of rectangular channel be B and depth of flow be y. Area of flow, A=By Wetted perimeter, [latex] P=B+2 y=\frac{A}{y}+2 y[/latex] For hydraulically most efficient section, P should be minimum. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \frac{d P}{d y}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{-A}{y^{2}}+2&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad A_{\theta}&=2 y_{e}^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad B_{e} y_{e}&=2 y_{\theta}^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad B_{\theta}&=2 y_{e} \end{aligned}[/latex] Hydraulic radius, [latex] R=\frac{A}{P}=\frac{2 y_{e}^{2}}{2 y_{e}+2 y_{e}}=\frac{y_{e}}{2}[/latex] Top width, [latex] T=B=2 y_{e}[/latex] Perimeter, [latex] P=B+2 y_{e}=2 y_{e}+2 y_{e}=4 y_{e} [/latex] Hydraulic depth, [latex] D=\frac{A}{T}=\frac{2 y_{e}^{2}}{2 y_{e}}=y_{e}[/latex]

Question 142 Water ([latex]\gamma _{w}= 9.879 kN/m^{3}[/latex]) 
 flows with a flow rate of 0.3 [latex]m^{3}/sec[/latex] through a pipe AB of 10 m length and of uniform cross-section. The end 'B' is above end 'A' and the
pipe makes an angle of 30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] to the horizontal. For a pressure of 12 [latex]kN/m^2[/latex] at the
end 'B', the corresponding pressure at the end 'A' is
solution: Applying Bernoulli's equation between A and B we get [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{p_{A}}{\gamma_{w}}+\frac{V^{2}}{2 g}+0 &=\frac{p_{B}}{\gamma_{w}}+\frac{V^{2}}{2 g}+z \\ \Rightarrow \quad p_{A}&=p_{B}+\gamma_{w} z \\ \Rightarrow \quad p_{A}&=12+9.879 \times 5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad p_{A}&=12+49.4 \\ &=61.4 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 143 A rectangular open channel of width 4.5 m is carrying a discharge of 100 [latex]m^{3}/ sec[/latex]. The critical depth of the channel is
solution: The critical depth for a rectangular channel is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} y_{c}^{3}&=\frac{q^{2}}{g}\\ \text{But }\quad q&=\frac{Q}{B}=\frac{100}{4.5}=22.22 \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{sec} \\ \therefore \quad y_{c}^{3}&=\frac{(22.22)^{2}}{9.81} \\ \Rightarrow \quad y_{c}&=3.69 m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 144 Water flows through a 100 mm diameter pipe with a velocity of 0.015 m/sec. If
the kinematic viscosity of water is [latex]1.13 \times 10^{-6}m^{2}/sec[/latex], the friction factor of the pipe material is
solution: Reynolds number. [latex] \begin{aligned} R e &=\frac{V D}{v}=\frac{0.015 \times 100 \times 10^{-3}}{1.13 \times 10^{-6}} \\ &=1327.43 \lt 2000 \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence flow is laminar [latex] \therefore \quad f=\frac{64}{\mathrm{Re}}=\frac{64}{1327.43}=0.048[/latex]

options.C: applicable to both prismatic and non-prismatic channels
options.D: not applicable to both prismatic and non-prismatic channels

question: Question 146 An automobile with projected area 2.6 [latex]m^{2}[/latex] is running on a road with a speed of 120 km per hour. The mass density and the kinematic viscosity of air are 1.2 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex] and [latex]1.5 \times 10^{-5} m^{2}/s[/latex], respectively. The drag coefficient is 0.30. The metric horse power required to overcome the drag force is
solution: Power required to overcome the drag = Drag force [latex] \times [/latex] velocity [latex]\begin{aligned} &=520 \times \frac{120 \times 1000}{60 \times 60}= 17333.33 \mathrm{watt} \\ &\quad (1 \mathrm{mhp}=735.5 \mathrm{watt})\\ &=\frac{17333.33}{735.5}\text{ metric horse power }\\ &=23.567 \text{ metric horse power} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 147 An automobile with projected area 2.6 [latex]m^{2}[/latex] is running on a road with a speed of 120 km per hour. The mass density and the kinematic viscosity of air are 1.2 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex] and [latex]1.5 \times 10^{-5} m^{2}/s[/latex], respectively. The drag coefficient is 0.30. The drag force on the automobile is
solution: The drag force on the automobile may be given as [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{D} &=C_{D} A \times \frac{\rho V^{2}}{2} \\ \text { Here, } C_{D} &=0.30, \\ A&=2.6 \mathrm{m}^{2}, \\ \rho&=1.2 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}, \\ V&=120 \mathrm{kmph} \\\text{So, }F_{D}&=0.30 \times 2.6 \times \frac{1.2 \times(120 \times 1000)^{2}}{2 \times(60 \times 60)^{2}}\\ &=520N \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 148 A rectangular channel 6.0 m wide carries a discharge of 16.0 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] under uniform
flow condition with normal depth of 1.60 m. Minning's n is 0.015. The channel width is to be contracted. The minimum width to which the channel
can be contracted without affecting the upstream flow condition is
solution: If the channel is contracted, the depth of flow at this location decreases. Thus width of the channel can be decreased till the specific energy becomes minimum. If the channel is contracted further, the depth of flow starts decreasing. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad y&+\frac{Q^{2}}{2 g A^{2}}=E_{\min } \\ \Rightarrow 1.6&+\frac{(16)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times(9.6)^{2}}=\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{y}_{\mathrm{c}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1.74&=\frac{3}{2} \times\left(\frac{\mathrm{Q}^{2} / \mathrm{b}^{2}}{\mathrm{g}}\right)^{1 / 3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1.74&=\frac{3}{2} \times\left[\frac{(16)^{2}}{9.81}\right]^{1 / 3} \times \frac{1}{(b)^{2 / 3}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad b^{2 / 3}&=2.557 \\ \Rightarrow \quad b&=4.1 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 149 A rectangular channel 6.0 m wide carries a discharge of 16.0 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] under uniform
flow condition with normal depth of 1.60 m. Minning's n is 0.015. A hump is to be provided on the channel bed. The maximum height of the hump
without affecting the upstream flow condition is
solution: When a hump is introduced on the channel bed the depth of flow at this location will reduce. If [latex]\Delta Z [/latex] is the maximum height of hump so that the depth of flow remains same, then [latex] \begin{aligned} y+\frac{Q^{2}}{2 g A^{2}}&=\Delta Z+E_{\min } \\ \Rightarrow 1.6+&\frac{(16)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times(9.6)^{2}}=\Delta Z+\frac{3}{2} y_{c} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 1.74&=\Delta Z+\frac{3}{2} \times\left[\frac{(16 / 6)^{2}}{9.81}\right]^{1 / 3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \Delta Z&=1.74-1.35 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \Delta Z&=0.39 \approx 0.4 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 150 A rectangular channel 6.0 m wide carries a discharge of 16.0 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] under uniform
flow condition with normal depth of 1.60 m. Minning's n is 0.015. The longitudinal slope of the channel is
solution: The velocity as per Manning's equation is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} V &=\frac{1}{n} R^{2 / 3} S^{1 / 2} \\ \text { Here, } Q &=16 m^{3} / s, n=0.015, B=6.0 m \\ A &=6.0 \times 1.60=9.6 m^{2} \\ R &=\frac{A}{P}=\frac{9.6}{6.0+(1.6 \times 2)}=1.04 m\\ \text{But }\quad Q&=A V \\ \therefore \quad Q&=A \times \frac{1}{n} R^{2 / 3} S^{1 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 16&=9.6 \times \frac{1}{0.015} \times(1.04)^{2 / 3} \times S^{1 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad S&=0.00059 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 151 A river reach of 2.0 km long with maximum flood discharge of 10000[latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] is to be physically modeled in the laboratory where maximum available discharge is 0.20 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex]. For a geometrically similar model based on equally of Froude number, the length of the river reach (m) in the model is
solution: According to Froude model law [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \frac{V_{t}}{\sqrt{L_{r} g_{1}}}&=1 \quad\left[\because F_{r}=1\right]\\ \text{Now, we have}\\ \frac{Q_{m}}{Q_{p}}&=L_{1}^{2} \times V_{r}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{Q_{m}}{Q_{p}}&=L_{r}^{2} \times \sqrt{L_{r}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{Q_{m}}{Q_{0}}&=\left(L_{r}\right)^{5 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{0.20}{10000}&=\left(\frac{L_{m}}{2 \times 1000}\right)^{5 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad L_{m}&=26.4 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 152 The flow of water (mass density = 100 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] and kinematic viscosity = [latex]10^{-6} m^{2}/s[/latex]) in a commercial pipe, having equivalent roughness [latex]k_{s}[/latex] as 0.12 mm, yields an average shear stress at the pipe boundary = 600 N/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]. The value of [latex]k_{s}/{\delta }'[/latex]
 ([latex]{\delta} '[/latex] being the thickness of laminar sub-layer) for this pipe is
solution: We know that, [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta^{\prime}&=\frac{11.6 \mathrm{v}}{V_{*}} \\ \text {But } V_{*}&=\sqrt{\frac{\tau_{0}}{\rho}} \\ \therefore \quad 8^{\prime} &=\frac{11.6 \mathrm{v}}{\sqrt{\tau_{0} / \mathrm{p}}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad & \delta=11.6 \times 10^{-6} \times \sqrt{\frac{1000}{600} \times 1000}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \delta^{\prime}&=0.015 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{k_{s}}{\delta^{\prime}}&=\frac{0.12}{0.015}=8.0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 153 A person standing on the bank of a canal drops a stone on the water surface. He
notices that the disturbance on the water surface is not travelling upstream. This
is because the flow in the canal is
solution:
For super-critical flow, [latex]F_{r} \gt 1 [/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\frac{V}{\sqrt{g y}} & \gt 1 \\
V & \gt \sqrt{g y} \\
V & \gt C
\end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, on upstream, the waves will be washed 
away and we will not be able to see them but 
they can be seen on downstream side. Hence, the flow here is super-critical.

question:
Question 154 A rectangular open channel needs to be designed to carry a flow of 2.0 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] under uniform flow conditions. The Manning's roughness coefficient is 0.018. The
channel should be such that the flow depth is equal to half the width, and the Froude
number is equal to 0.5 Keeping the width, flow depth and roughness the same, if the bed slope of the
above channel is double, the average boundary shear stress under uniform flow
conditions is
solution: The average shear stress, [latex]\tau_{0}=\gamma \mathrm{RS}_{0} [/latex] Bed slope is doubled i.e. [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{0} &=2 \times 0.0021=0.0042 \\ \therefore \quad \tau &=9810 \times \frac{0.836}{2} \times 0.0042 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tau_{0} &=17.22 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 155 A rectangular open channel needs to be designed to carry a flow of 2.0 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] under uniform flow conditions. The Manning's roughness coefficient is 0.018. The
channel should be such that the flow depth is equal to half the width, and the Froude
number is equal to 0.5 The bed slope of the channel to be provided is
solution: Given [latex]Q=2 m^{3} / s, n=0.018, B=2 y, F=0.5 [/latex] We know that [latex] F=\frac{V}{\sqrt{g D}} [/latex] where V is velocity of flow, D is hydraulic radius [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Now }D=\frac{A}{T}&=\frac{B y}{B}=y \\ \therefore \quad F&=\frac{Q}{A \sqrt{g y}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.5&=\frac{2}{2 y^{2} \times \sqrt{g y}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.5&=\frac{1}{y^{2} \sqrt{g y}}[ \text{ Squaring both sides }] \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow 0.25&=\frac{1}{g y^{5}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad y&=\left(\frac{1}{0.25 \times 9.81}\right)^{1 / 5} \\ \Rightarrow \quad y&=0.836 \mathrm{m} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Using Manning's equation, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=\frac{1}{n} A(R)^{2 / 3} \sqrt{S} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 2&=\frac{1}{0.018} \times\left[2 \times(0.836)^{2}\right] \\ &\times\left(\frac{0.836}{2}\right)^{2 / 3} \sqrt{S} \\ \Rightarrow \sqrt{S}&=0.0461 \\ \Rightarrow \quad S&=0.0021 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 156 The flow rate in a wide rectangular open channel is 2.0 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] per metre width. The
channel bed slope is 0.002. The Manning's roughness coefficient is 0.012. The slope of the channel is classified as
solution: The critical depth for a rectangular channel is given by [latex] y_{c}=\left(\frac{q^{2}}{g}\right)^{1 / 3}=\left(\frac{(2)^{2}}{9.81}\right)^{1 / 3}=0.74 m[/latex] Using Manning's equation, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} & q=\frac{1}{n}\left(y_{n}\right)^{5 / 3} \sqrt{S} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 2&=\frac{1}{0.012} \times\left(y_{n}\right)^{5 / 3} \times \sqrt{0.002}\\ \Rightarrow \quad y_{n}&=0.69 \mathrm{m} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] For steep slopes [latex]y_{n} \lt y_{c}[/latex]

question: Question 157 Flow rate of a fluid (density = 1000 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]) in a small diameter tube is 800 [latex]mm^{3}/s[/latex]. The length and the diameter of the tube are 2 m and 0.5 mm, respectively. The pressure drop in 2 m length is equal to 2.0 MPa. The viscosity of the fluid is
solution: Applying Hagen-Poiseuille equation, the drop in pressure is given by, [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{1}-p_{2} &=\frac{32 \mu V L}{D^{2}} \\ \text{But}\quad Q &=A V \\ \Rightarrow\quad V &=\frac{Q}{A} \\ &=\frac{800 \times 4}{\pi \times(0.5)^{2}} \\ &=4074.37 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{s} \simeq 4.07 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \therefore \quad 2 \times 10^{6} &=\frac{32 \times \mu \times 4.07 \times 2}{\left(0.5 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{2}} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \mu &=1.92 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{Ns} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ &=0.00192 \mathrm{Ns} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 158 A triangle open channel has a vertex angle of [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex] and carries flow at a critical depth of 0.30 m. The discharge in the channel is
solution: The side slope of triangle open channel is given as z horizontal to 1 vertical When vertex angle is [latex]90^{\circ},z=1[/latex] Now, [latex]y_{c}=\left(\frac{2 Q^{2}}{g z^{2}}\right)^{1 / 5}[/latex] for a triangular channel [latex] \Rightarrow \quad Q^{2}=\frac{g z^{2}\left(y_{c}\right)^{5}}{2} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad Q^{2}=\frac{9.81 \times(1)^{2} \times(0.30)^{5}}{2} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad Q=0.11 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question: Question 159 A 1:50 scale model of a spillway is to be tested in the laboratory. The discharge in the prototype is 1000 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex]. The discharge to be maintained in the model test is
solution: Froude model law will be applicable in this case [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{Q_{m}}{Q_{p}} &=\left(\frac{L_{m}}{L_{p}}\right)^{5 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad Q_{m} &=1000 \times\left(\frac{1}{50}\right)^{25} \\ &=0.057 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 160 A horizontal water jet with a velocity of 10 m/s and cross sectional area of 10
[latex]mm^{2}[/latex] strikes a flat plate held normal to the flow direction. The density of water
is 1000 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The total force on the plate due to the jet is
solution: The force is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} F &=\rho a V^{2} \\ \therefore F &=1000 \times 10 \times 10^{-6} \times(10)^{2} \\ &=1 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 161 At two point 1 and 2 in a pipeline the velocities are V and 2V, respectively. Both
the points are at the same elevation. The fluid density is [latex]\rho[/latex]. The flow can be
assumed to be incompressible, inviscid, steady and irrotational. The difference in
pressures [latex]P_{1}[/latex]
 and [latex]P_{2}[/latex] at point 1 and 2 is
solution: Applying Bernoulli's equation, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{P_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{(V)^{2}}{2 g}+Z&=\frac{P_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{(2 V)^{2}}{2 g}+z \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{P_{1}-P_{2}}{\rho g}&=\frac{4 V^{2}-V^{2}}{2 g} \\ \Rightarrow \quad P_{1}-P_{2}&=\frac{3}{2} p V^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad P_{1}-P_{2}&=1.5 p V^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 162 There is a free overfall at the end of a long open channel. For a given flow rate,
the critical depth is less than the normal depth. What gradually varied flow
profile will occur in the channel for this flow rate ?
solution:
All free fall curves are zone II profiles. since the 
critical depth [latex] \left(\mathrm{y}_{\mathrm{c}}\right) [/latex] is less than the normal depth 
[latex] \left(y_{n}\right), [/latex] therefore the slope is mild. Thus, the 
gradually varied profile is [latex] \mathrm{M}_{2} [/latex]

question:
Question 163 An upward flow of oil (mass density 800 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex], dynamic viscosity 0.8 kg/m-s) 
takes place under laminar conditions in an inclined pipe of 0.1 m diameter as shown
in the figure. The pressures at sections 1 and 2 are measured as [latex]p_1 = 435 kN/m^2[/latex]
and [latex]p_2 = 200 kN/m^2[/latex]. If the flow is reversed, keeping the same discharge and the pressure at section 1
is maintained as 435 [latex]kN/m^{2}[/latex], the pressure at section 2 is equal to
solution: When the flow is reversed, then [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\rho_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{32\mu VL}{\rho g D^{2}}&=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+5 \sin45^{\circ}\\ \Rightarrow \frac{435\times 10^{3}}{800\times 9.81}&+\frac{32\times 0.8 \times 16.19 \times 5}{800\times 9.81\times (0.1)^{2}}\\ &=\frac{\rho_{2}}{800\times 9.81}+\frac{5}{\sqrt{2}}\\ \Rightarrow p_{2} &= 614.48kH/m^{2} = 614kN/m^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 164 An upward flow of oil (mass density 800 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex], dynamic viscosity 0.8 kg/m-s) 
takes place under laminar conditions in an inclined pipe of 0.1 m diameter as shown
in the figure. The pressures at sections 1 and 2 are measured as [latex]p_1 = 435 kN/m^2[/latex]
and [latex]p_2 = 200 kN/m^2[/latex]. The discharge in the pipe is equal to
solution: Applying Bornouth's equation between (1) and (2) [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\rho_{1}}{\rho g}&=\frac{\rho_{2}}{\rho g}+\sin 45^{\circ}+\frac{32\mu VL}{\rho gD^{2}}\\ \Rightarrow \frac{430\times 10^{3}200\times 10^{3}}{800\times }&-\frac{5}{\sqrt{2}}\\ &=\frac{32\times 0.8\times 5}{800\times 9.81 \times (0.1)^{2}}\\ \Rightarrow V&=16.19 m/s\\ \therefore Q=AV\\ &= \frac{\pi \times (0.1)^{}}{4} \times 16.19\\ &=0.127m^{3}/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 165 The flow of glycerin (kinematic viscosity [latex]v = 5 \times 10^{-4}m^{2}/s[/latex]) in an open channel
is to be modeled in a laboratory flume using water ([latex]v = 10^{-6}m^{2}/s[/latex]) as the flowing fluid. If both gravity and viscosity are important, what should be the length scale
(i.e. ratio of prototype to model dimensions) for maintaining dynamic similarity ?
solution: Equating Reynolds number and Froude number, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{V_{t} L}{v_{r}} &=\frac{V_{r}}{\sqrt{L}} \\ \therefore\quad L_{r} &=\left(v_{r}\right)^{2 / 3} \\ v_{r} &=\frac{v_{m}}{v_{p}}=\frac{10^{-6}}{5 \times 10^{-4}}=2 \times 10^{-3} \\ \Rightarrow\quad L_{r} &=\left(2 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{2 / 3} \\ \Rightarrow\quad L_{r} &=0.0159 \quad \text { But } \cdot L_{r}=\frac{L_{m}}{L_{p}} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \frac{L_{p}}{L_{m}} &=\frac{1}{L_{r}}=\frac{1}{0.0159}=62.99 \approx 63 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 166 A very wide rectangular channel is designed to carry a discharge of 5 [latex]m^3/s[/latex] per
meter width. The design is based on the Manning's equation with the roughness
coefficient obtained from the grain size using Strickler's equation and results in a
normal depth of 1.0 m. By mistake, however, the engineer used the grain diameter
in mm in the Strickler's equation instead of in meter. What should be the correct
normal depth?
solution: As per Strickler's equation, [latex]n=\frac{d^{1 / 6}}{24} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \frac{n_{\text {correct }}}{n_{\text {wrong }}}=\left(\frac{1}{1000}\right)^{1 / 6} [/latex] Now, as per Mannings equation, [latex] q=\frac{1}{n}(y)^{5 / 3} \sqrt{S}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Correct depth of flow, [latex] \begin{aligned} y_{\text {contect }} &=\left(\frac{n_{\text {correct }}}{n_{\text {wrong }}}\right)^{3 / 5} \times y_{\text {wrong }} \\ &=\left[\left(\frac{1}{1000}\right)^{1 / 6}\right]^{3 / 5} \times 1 \\ &=0.50 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 167 A hydraulic jump occurs in a rectangular, horizontal, frictonless channel. What
would be the pre-jump depth if the discharge per unit width is 2 [latex]m^{3}/s/m[/latex] and the energy loss is 1 m ?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{2 q^{2}}{g} &=y_{1} y_{2}\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right) \quad \ldots(i)\\ H_{L} &=\frac{\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{3}}{4 y_{1} y_{2}} \quad\ldots(ii)\\ \text{Given,}\\ H_{L} &=1 \mathrm{m} \\ \left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{3} &=4 \mathrm{y}_{1} \cdot \mathrm{y}_{2}\\ \text{Put,}\quad y_{2}&=m y_{1} \text { in equation (ii) } \\ y_{1}&=\frac{4 m}{(m-1)^{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Similarly, put [latex] y_{2}=m y_{1} [/latex] in equation (i), we get [latex] \begin{array}{l} m(m+1) y_{1}^{3}=\frac{2 \times 2^{2}}{9.81}=0.8155 \\ m(m+1)\left\{\frac{4 m}{(m-1)^{3}}\right\}^{3}=0.8155\\ \frac{m(m+1)\left(m^{3}\right)}{(m-1)^{9}}=\frac{0.8155}{4^{3}}\\ \text{By trial and error,} m=5.09 \\ y_{1}=0.3 \mathrm{m} \\ y_{2}=1.527 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 168 The velocity field for a flow is given by : [latex]\vec{V}=(5x+6y+7z)\vec{i}[/latex] + [latex](6x+5y+9z)\vec{j}[/latex] + [latex](3x+2y+\lambda z)\vec{k}[/latex] and the density varies as [latex]\rho =\rho _{0}exp(-2t)[/latex]. In order that the mass is conserved, the value of [latex]\lambda[/latex] should be
solution: The continuity equation is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial p}{\partial t}&+\frac{\partial(p u)}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial(\rho v)}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial(p w)}{\partial z}=0 \\ \text{Now,}\quad \rho&=\rho_{0} e^{-2 t} \\ \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t} &=-2 \rho_{0} e^{-2 t}=-2 p \\ p \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}=5 p, p \frac{\partial v}{\partial y}&=5 p, p \frac{\partial w}{\partial z}=\lambda p \\ \therefore-2 p+5 p+5 p&+\lambda p=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 8 p+\lambda p&=0 \\ \text{or} \quad 8+\lambda&=0 \\ \text{or} \quad \lambda&=-8 \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 169 The thickness of the laminar boundary layer on a flat plate at a point A is 2 cm
and at a point B, 1 m downstream of A, is 3 cm. What is the distance of A from the leading edge of the plate ?
solution: Laminar boundary layer thickness, [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta &=5 \sqrt{\frac{x v}{V}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\delta_{A}}{\delta_{B}} &=\sqrt{\frac{x_{A}}{x_{B}}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{2}{3} &=\sqrt{\frac{x_{A}}{x_{A}+1}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{4}{9}&=\frac{x_{A}}{x_{A}+1} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 5x_{A}&=4 \\ \Rightarrow x_{A}&= 0.8 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 170 Identify the FALSE statement from the following: The specific speed of the pump increases with
solution: The specific speed of a pump is given by, [latex] N_{S}=\frac{N \sqrt{Q}}{\left(H_{m}\right)^{3 / 4}}[/latex]

question:
Question 171 A channel with a mild slope is followed by a horizontal channel and then by a
steep channel. What gradually varied flow profiles will occur?
Question 172 The necessary and sufficient condition for a surface to be called as a free surface is

options.A: no stress should be acting on it
options.B: tensile stress acting on it must be zero

question: Question 173 A triangular irrigation lined canal carries a discharge of 25 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s at bed slope =[latex]\frac{1}{6000}[/latex]. If the side slopes of the canal are 1:1 and Manning's coefficient is 0.018, the central depth of flow is equal to
solution: By Manning's equation, [latex]Q=\frac{1}{n} R^{2 / 3} S^{1 / 2} A [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad 25&=\frac{1}{0.018} \times\left(\frac{y}{2 \sqrt{2}}\right)^{2 / 3} \times\left(\frac{1}{6000}\right)^{1 / 2} \times(y)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 25&=\frac{1}{0.018} \times(y)^{8 / 3} \times \frac{1}{154.92} \\ \Rightarrow \quad y&=4.91 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 174 A tank and a deflector are placed on a frictionless trolley. The tank issues water
jet (mass density of water = 1000 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]), which strikes the deflector and turns by 45[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. If the velocity of jet leaving the deflector is 4 m/s and discharge is 0.1
[latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s, the force recorded by the spring will be
solution: Force in spring will be the force in horizonta direction. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad F_{H} &=\rho Q V \cos \theta \\ &=1000 \times 0.1 \times 4 \times \cos 45^{\circ} \\ &=\frac{400}{\sqrt{2}}=200 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 175 The circulation 'G' around a circle of radius 2 units for the velocity field u=2x+3y
and v=-2y is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Circulation } &=\text { Vorticity } \times \text { Area } \\ &=\left(\frac{\partial v}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}\right) \times \text { Area } \\ &=(0-3) \times \pi \times(2)^{2} \\ &=-12 \pi \text { units } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 176 Cross-section of an object (having same section normal to the paper) submerged
into a fluid consists of a square of sides 2 m and triangle as shown in the figure.
The object is hinged at point P that is one meter below the fluid free surface. If
the object is to be kept in the position as shown in the figure, the value of 'x'
should be
solution: The vertical force on the surface bounded by square and triangle would be respectively, [latex] F_{1}=4(S-1) \gamma_{w} [/latex] for square edge and acting at 1 m from P [latex] F_{2}=x(S-1) \gamma_{w}[/latex] for inclined edge of triangle and acting at x / 3 from P Taking moments of both the forces about P, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{ 1} \times 1 &=F_{2} \times \frac{x}{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 4(\mathrm{S}-1) \gamma_{w} &=x(S-1) \gamma_{w} \times \frac{x}{3} \\ \Rightarrow \quad x^{2} &=12 \\ \Rightarrow \quad x &=2 \sqrt{3} \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 177 A stream function is given by [latex]\Psi =2x^{2}y+(x+1)y^{2}[/latex] The flow rate across a line joining points A(3,0) and B(0,2) is
solution: The rate of flow is the difference in value of stream function at points A and B [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad Q &=\left|\psi_{A}-\psi_{B}\right| \\ \psi_{A} &=2 \times(3)^{2} \times 0+(3+1) \times(0)^{2}=0 \\ \psi_{B} &=2 \times(0)^{2} \times 2+(0+1) \times(2)^{2}=4 \\ \therefore & Q=|0-4|=4 \text { units } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 178 A partially open sluice gate discharge water into a rectangular channel. The tail
water depth in the channel is 3 m and Froude number is [latex]\frac{1}{2\sqrt{2}}[/latex]. If a free hydraulic jump is to be formed at downstream of the sluice gate after the
vena contracta of the jet coming out from the sluice gate, the sluice gate opening
should be (coefficient of contraction [latex]C_c[/latex]=0.9)
solution: For hydraulic jump, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{y_{1}}{y_{2}}&=\frac{1}{2}\left[-1+\sqrt{1+8 F_{2}^{2}}\right]\\ \text{Given},\quad y_{2}&=3 \mathrm{m} \\ F_{2} &=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2}} \\ \therefore \quad y_{1} &=\frac{3}{2}\left[-1+\sqrt{1+8 \times \frac{1}{4 \times 2}}\right]\\ \Rightarrow \quad y_{1}&=0.62 \mathrm{m} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Sluice gate opening [latex] =\frac{y_{1}}{C_{c}}=\frac{0.62}{0.9}=0.69 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question:
Question 179 Critical depth at a section of a rectangular channel is 1.5 m. The specific energy
at that section is
solution: For Rectanguler channel, [latex] E_{c}= 1.5y_{c}=1.5\times 1.5=2.25m[/latex]

question:
Question 180 The reading of differential manometer of a Venturimeter, placed at 45[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] to the
horizontal is 11 cm. If the Venturimeter is turned to horizontal position, the
manometer reading will be
solution:
The manomeler reading of a venturimeter does not depend upon the inclination of venturimeter
with the horizontal

question:
Question 181 A horizontal bed channel is followed by a steep bed channel as shown in the
figure. The gradually-varied profiles over the horizontal and sleep beds are
solution:
When a flow profile change from subcritical to 
supercritical flow, critical depth act as a control 
point.

question:
Question 182 An inert tracer is injected continuously from a point in an unsteady flow field.
The locus of locations of all tracer particles at an instance of time represents
solution:
Streamline: A stream line is an imaginary curve that is every where tangent to the instantaneous
local velocity vector. Pathline: Actual path travelled by any individual fluid partial over a time period is called pathline Streamtube: It is formed by the group of
streamlines Streakline: It is locus of all fluid particles passing through a fixed point at a particular time.

question:
Question 183 The laminar flow takes place between closely spaced parallel plates as shown in
figure below. The velocity profile is given by [latex]u=V\frac{y}{h}[/latex]. The gap height, h, is 5 mm
and the space is filled with oil (specific gravity=0.86, viscosity m=[latex]2 \times 10^{-4}N-s/m^2[/latex]). The bottom plate is stationery and the top plate moves with a steady velocity
of V = 5 cm/s. The area of the plate is 0.25[latex]m^2[/latex]. The power required to keep the plate in steady motion is
solution: Shear stress. [latex] \tau=\frac{\mu \partial U}{\partial y}=\frac{\mu V}{h}[/latex] Shear force. [latex] F=\tau A[/latex] Power required to keep the plate in steady motion [latex] \begin{aligned} &=F \times\text{ Velocity}\\ &=\tau A \times V=\frac{\mu V}{h} \times A \times V \\ &=\frac{\mu V^{2} A}{h}=\frac{2 \times 10^{-4} \times\left(5 \times 10^{-2}\right)^{2} \times 0.25}{5 \times 10^{3}} \\ &=2.5 \times 10^{-5} \text{ Watts} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 184 The laminar flow takes place between closely spaced parallel plates as shown in
figure below. The velocity profile is given by [latex]u=V\frac{y}{h}[/latex]. The gap height, h, is 5 mm
and the space is filled with oil (specific gravity=0.86, viscosity m=[latex]2 \times 10^{-4}N-s/m^2[/latex]). The bottom plate is stationery and the top plate moves with a steady velocity
of V = 5 cm/s. The area of the plate is 0.25[latex]m^2[/latex]. The rate of rotation of a fluid particle is given by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given } u&=\frac{V y}{h} \\ v&=0 \text { and } w=0\\ a_{x}&=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial w}{\partial y}-\frac{\partial v}{\partial z}\right)=\frac{1}{2}(0-0)=0 \\ \omega_{y}&=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial z}-\frac{\partial w}{\partial x}\right)=\frac{1}{2}(0-0)=0 \\ \omega_{z}&=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial v}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left(0-\frac{V}{h}\right)=\frac{-V}{2 n} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:

observed to be 10 cm. The corresponding prototype height of the jump is

question:
Question 186 The allowable Net Positive Sustion Head (NPSH) for a pump provided by the
manufacturer for a flow of 0.05 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s is 3.3 m. The temperature of water is [latex]30^{\circ}C[/latex] (vapour pressure head absolute = 0.44 m), atmosphere pressure is 100 kPa absolute and the head loss from the reservoir to pump is 0.3 N-m/N. The maximum height of the pump above the sustion reservoir is
solution: The maximum suction lift, [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{s}&=\left(\frac{p_{a}-p_{v}}{\gamma_{w}}\right)-N P S H-h_{ts} \\ p_{a} &=100 k P a_{i} \\ \gamma_{w} &=1000 \times 9.81=9810 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \frac{p_{v}}{\gamma_{w}} &=0.44 \mathrm{m} \\ \frac{p_{a}}{\gamma_{w}} &=\frac{100 \times 10^{3}}{9810}=10.19 \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore \quad h_{s} &=10.19-0.44-3.3-0.3 \\ &=6.15 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 187 The velocity in m/s at a point in a two-dimensional flow is given as [latex]\vec{V}=2\vec{i}+3\vec{j}[/latex]. The equation of the stream line passing through the point is
solution: The equation of stream line in two dimensions is given as [latex] \begin{array}{rr} & v d x-u d y=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad & 3 d x-2 d y=0 \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 188 A steep wide rectangular channel takes off from a reservoir having an elevation
of 101.2 m. At the entrance, the bottom elevation of the channel is 100 m. If
the slope of the channel is increased by 4%, the discharge per unit length in the
channel will be
solution:
It is a example of super critical canal intake, the 
reservoir water surface falls to the critical depth 
at the head of the canal and then towards the 
water surface follows the [latex]S_{2}[/latex] Curve. The critical 
depth occurring at the u/s end of the channel is 
the control for this flow. And critical depth only depends upon channel 
geometry not the slope. [latex]
\begin{aligned}
E_{c} &=101.2-100 \\
&=1.2 m \\
y_{c} &=\frac{2}{3} E_{c}=0.8 m \\
y_{c} &=\left(\frac{q^{2}}{g}\right)^{1 / 3} \\
q &=2.24 m^{2} / s e c
\end{aligned}[/latex] Note: On changing the slope discharge will not 
change; but velocity and depth vary with slope.

question: Question 189 A steady flow occurs in an open channel with lateral inflow of [latex]q \; m^{3}/s[/latex] per unit width as shown in the figure. The mass conservation equation is
solution: Considering an element of width dx The mass conservation equation will be [latex] \begin{aligned} Q+q d x-\left(Q+\frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} d x\right)&=0 \\ \therefore \quad Q+q d x-Q-\frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} d x &=0 \\ \therefore \quad \frac{\partial Q}{\partial x}-q &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 190 A fire protection system is supplied from a water tower with a bent pipe as shown
in the figure. The pipe friction f is 0.03. Ignoring all minor losses, the maximum
discharge, Q in the pipe is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H&=\frac{8 Q^{2}}{\pi^{2} g} \frac{f L}{D^{5}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 25&=\frac{8 Q^{2}}{\pi^{2} g} \times \frac{(0.03)(175)}{(0.1)^{5}} \\ Q&=24 \text { litre/sec } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 191 A thin flat plate [latex]0.5m\times 0.7m[/latex] in size settles in a large tank of water with a terminal velocity of 0.12 m/s. The coefficients of drag [latex]C_{D}=\frac{1.328}{\sqrt{R_{L}}}[/latex] for a laminar boundary layer and [latex]C_{D}=\frac{0.072}{(R_{L})^{1/5}}[/latex] for a turbulent boundary layer, where [latex]R_L[/latex] is the plate Reynolds number. Assume [latex]\mu=10^{-3} N-s/m^{2}[/latex] and [latex]\rho =1000 kg/m^{3}[/latex] The submerged weight of the plate is
solution: The critical Reynolds number for flat plates is [latex] 5 \times 10^{5} [/latex] As [latex]R_{L} \lt [/latex] critical Reynolds number thus laminar boundary layer will grow through out the length [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore C_{0}&=\frac{1.328}{\sqrt{R_{L}}}=\frac{1328}{\sqrt{84 \times 10^{3}}}=4.58 \times 10^{-3}\\ \therefore &\quad \text{Drag force.}\\ F_{0} &=2 C_{D} A\left(\frac{\rho V^{2}}{2}\right) \\ &=4.58 \times 10^{-3} \times 0.5 \times 0.7 \times 1000 \times(0.12)^{2} \\ &=0.0231 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 192 A velocity field is given as [latex]\vec{V}=2y\vec{i}+3x\vec{j}[/latex], where x and y are in metres. The acceleration of a fluid particle at (x,y)=(1,1) in the x direction is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given } \quad \nabla&=2 y \hat{\imath}+3 x \hat{\jmath}\\ u&=2 y and v=3 x \\ a_{x}&=\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}+u \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+v \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} \\ \Rightarrow \quad a_{x}&=0+(2 y \times 0)+(3 x \times 2) \\ \Rightarrow \quad a_{x}&=6 x\\ \text{Now at }(1,1)\\ a_{1}&=6 x=6 \times 1=6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 193 A wide channel is 1 m deep and has a velocity of flow, V, as 2.13 m/s. If a
disturbance is caused, an elementary wave can travel upstream with a velocity of
solution:
[latex]F_{\mathrm{r}}=\frac{V}{C_{0}}=\frac{\text { Flow speed }}{\text { Wave speed }}[/latex] At low speed, [latex]F_{t} \lt 1;[/latex] a small disturbance travels 
u/s (with a velocity [latex]C_{0}-V[/latex] relative to a stationary 
observer) and affects the u/s conditions. At high flow velocities, [latex]F_{r} \gt 1[/latex], a small disturbance 
travels d/s at a velocity of [latex]\mathrm{V}-\mathrm{C}_{0}[/latex] relative to a 
stationary observer. (As [latex]\mathrm{V} \gt \mathrm{C}_{0}[/latex] small disturbance 
can not travel u/s) and thus the u/s conditions 
can not be influenced by the d/s conditions and 
the flow is controlled by the u/s conditions. 
Therefore, we can say that the region which 
remains unaffected controls the flow. [latex]
F_{r}=\frac{2.13}{\sqrt{9.81 \times 1}}=0.68 \lt 1[/latex] (Subcritical flow) [latex]
C_{0}=\sqrt{9.81 \times 1}=3.13 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] An elementary wave travels u/s with a velocity [latex]
 C_{0}-V[/latex] relative to a stationary observer [latex]
 =3.13-2.13=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} [/latex]

Area, [latex]A=\frac{\pi r^{2}}{2} [/latex] Top width, [latex]

 \therefore[/latex] Hydraulic depth [latex]

is the cross sectional area and V is the velocity of flow, the forces exerted on
segment 1-2 of the pipe in the x and y direction are, respectively,
