question:
Question 196 An aircraft is flying in level flight at a speed of 200 km/hr through air (density,
[latex]\rho =1.2 kg/m^{3}[/latex], and viscosity [latex]\mu =1.6 \times 10^{-5} Ns/m^{2}[/latex]). The lift coefficient at this speed is 0.4 and the drag coefficient is 0.0065. The mass of the aircraft is 800 kg. The effective lift area of the aircraft is
solution: The lift force will be equal to self weight of the aircraft for equilibrium [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{L} &=W \\ \Rightarrow C_{L} A_{L} \frac{\rho V^{2}}{2} &=m g\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{0.4 \times A_{L} \times 1.2 \times\left(\frac{200 \times 10^{3}}{60 \times 60}\right)^{2}}{2}&=800 \times 9.81\\ A_{L}&=10.6 \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 197 The x component of velocity in a two dimensional incompressible flow is given
by u=1.5x. At the point (x,y) = (1,0), the y component of velocity v=0. The
equation for the y component of velocity is
solution:
For equation of stream line in two dimensions is given as [latex]
\begin{aligned}
 \frac{\partial U}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial V}{\partial y}&=0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad 1.5+\frac{\partial V}{\partial y} &=0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{\partial V}{\partial y}&=-1.5 \\
\Rightarrow \quad v&=-1.5 \mathrm{y}+\mathrm{C}\\
\text { But at } \quad y&=0, v=0\\
\therefore \quad 0&=-15 \times 0+C \\
\Rightarrow \quad C&=0\\
\text { Thus } \quad v&=-1.5 \mathrm{y}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 198 In the inclined manometer shown in the figure below, the reservoir is large. Its
surface may be assumed to remain at a fixed elevation. A is connected to a gas
pipeline and the deflection noted on the inclined glass tube is 100 mm. Assuming
[latex]\theta =30^{\circ}[/latex] and the manometric fluid as oil with specific gravity of 0.86, the pressure at A is
solution: Total pressure at A will be equal to the pressure at the surface of manometric fluid because above the surface, the gas pipeline is connected. [latex] \therefore[/latex] Pressure at [latex]A=100 \sin 30^{\circ} \mathrm{mm}[/latex] of oil [latex] =50 \mathrm{mm} \text { of oil }[/latex] We know that [latex] \begin{aligned} S_{1} h_{1} &=S_{2} h_{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.86 \times 50 &=1 \times h_{2} \\ \Rightarrow &=43 \mathrm{mm} \text { of water } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 199 A pipeline (diameter 0.3 m, length 3 km) carries water form point P to point R
(see figure). The piezometric heads at P and R are to be maintained at 100 m and
80 m, respectively. To increase the discharge, a second pipe is added in parallel to
the existing pipe form Q to R. The length of the additional pipe is also 2 km.
Assume the friction factor, f=0.04 for all pipes and ignore minor losses. If there is no restriction on the diameter of the additional pipe, what would be
the maximum increase in discharge theoretically possible from this arrangement ?
solution: If the diameter of additional pipe is very large, the head loss will be zero in it theoretically. Therefore the total head loss will occur between P and Q only [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{L}&=\frac{f L_{P Q} Q_{3}^{2}}{12 d^{5}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 20&=\frac{0.04 \times 1000 \times Q_{3}^{2}}{12 \times(0.3)^{5}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad Q_{3}&=0.1207 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned} [/latex] % maximum increase in discharge [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\left(\frac{Q_{3}-Q_{1}}{Q_{1}}\right) \times 100 \\ &=\left(\frac{0.1207-0.0697}{0.0697}\right) \times 100 \\ &=73.17 \% \approx 73 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 200 A pipeline (diameter 0.3 m, length 3 km) carries water form point P to point R
(see figure). The piezometric heads at P and R are to be maintained at 100 m and
80 m, respectively. To increase the discharge, a second pipe is added in parallel to
the existing pipe form Q to R. The length of the additional pipe is also 2 km.
Assume the friction factor, f=0.04 for all pipes and ignore minor losses. What is the increase in discharge if the additional pipe has same diameter (0.3 m) ?
solution: The difference between piezometric head between P and R is 100-80=20m. Now, if the minor losses are neglected, then the only loss is the head loss. Let the initial discharge be [latex]Q_{1} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad h_{L}&=\frac{f L Q_{1}^{2}}{12 d^{5}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 20&=\frac{0.04 \times 3000 \times 0_{1}^{2}}{12 \times(0.3)^{5}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad Q_{1}&=0.0697 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{L}&=h_{PQ}+h_{QR}\\ \therefore \quad 20&=\frac{f L_{P Q} Q_{2}^{2}}{12 \times(0.3)^{5}}+\frac{f L_{0 R}\left(\frac{Q_{2}}{2}\right)^{2}}{12 \times(0.3)^{5}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 20&=\frac{0.04 \times 1000 \times 0_{2}^{2}}{12 \times(0.3)^{5}}+\frac{0.04 \times 2000 \times 0_{2}^{2}}{4 \times 12 \times(0.3)^{5}} \\ \Rightarrow Q_{2}&=0.0986m^{3}/s \end{aligned}[/latex] % increase in discharge [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\left(\frac{Q_{2}-Q_{1}}{Q_{1}}\right) \times 100 \\\\ =\left(\frac{0.0986-0.0697}{0.0697}\right) \times 100 \\ =41.4 \% \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 201 A very wide rectangular channel carries a discharge of 8 [latex]m^3/s[/latex] per m width. The
channel has a bed slope of 0.004 and Manning's roughness coefficient, n = 0.015.
At a certain section of the channel, the flow depth is 1 m. At what distance from this section the flow depth will be 0.9 m ?
(use the direct step method employing a single step.)

Question 202 A very wide rectangular channel carries a discharge of 8 [latex]m^3/s[/latex] per m width. The
channel has a bed slope of 0.004 and Manning's roughness coefficient, n = 0.015.
At a certain section of the channel, the flow depth is 1 m. What Gradually Varied Flow profile exists at this section ?
solution: Critical depth, [latex] y_{c}=\left(\frac{q^{2}}{g}\right)^{1 / 3}=\left(\frac{8^{2}}{9.81}\right)^{1 / 3}=1.868 m[/latex] From Manning's equation, we have [latex] \begin{aligned} q&=\frac{1}{n}\left(y_{n}\right)^{5 / 3} S^{1 / 2}\\ \Rightarrow \quad 8&=\frac{1}{0.015} \times\left(y_{n}\right)^{5 / 3}(0.004)^{1 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad y_{n}&=1.468 m \\ \text{Given that}\\ y&=1 m\\ \because \quad y_{c}&>y_{n}>y \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] The gradually varied profile will be [latex]S_{3}[/latex]

question: Question 203 A solid sphere (diameter 6 mm) is rising through oil (mass density 900 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex], dynamic viscosity 0.7 kg/ms) at a constant velocity of 1 cm/s. What is the specific weight of the material form which the sphere is made ? (Take g = 9.81 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex])
solution: The solid sphere will be acted upon by three forces viz. drag force [latex]\left(\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{D}}\right)[/latex], force of buoyancy [latex]\left(\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{B}}\right)[/latex] and self weight of sphere (W) [latex] \begin{array}{l} W=\rho_{s} V g \\ F_{B}=\rho_{0} V g \\ F_{D}=C_{D} A \frac{\rho_{0} V^{2}}{2} \end{array}[/latex] Reynolds Number, [latex] \begin{aligned} \mathrm{Re} &=\frac{\rho_{0} \mathrm{VD}}{\mu} \\ &=\frac{900 \times 1 \times 10^{-2} \times 6 \times 10^{-3}}{0.7} \\ &=0.07714 \lt 0.2(\mathrm{ok}) \\\; \therefore \quad \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{D}} &=\frac{24}{\mathrm{Re}}=\frac{24}{0.07714}=311.12 \end{aligned}[/latex] Now, from the free body diagram, we have [latex]W+F_{D}=F_{B} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \quad W&=F_{B}-F_{D} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \rho_{s} V g&=\rho_{0} V g-C_{D} A \frac{\rho_{0} V^{2}}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad w_{\mathrm{s}} V&=\rho_{0} V g-C_{D} \frac{A \rho_{0} V^{2}}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad w_{\mathrm{s}}&=\rho_{0} g-\frac{C_{\mathrm{D}} A \rho_{0} v^{2}}{2 V} \\ \Rightarrow \quad w_{\mathrm{s}}&=900 \times 9.81 \\ & -\frac{\left[\begin{array}{l}6 \times 311.12 \times \pi \times\left(6 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{2} \\ \times 900 \times\left(1 \times 10^{-2}\right)^{2}\end{array}\right]}{4 \times \pi \times\left(6 \times 10^{-3}\right)^{3}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad w_{\mathrm{s}}&=5328.9 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{3}=5.3 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 204 Two pipelines, one carrying oil (mass density 900 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]) and the other water, are connected to a manometer as shown in figure. By what amount the pressure
in the water pipe should be increased so that the mercury levels in both the limbs
of the manometer become equal ? (mass density of mercury= 13550 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] and g = 9.81 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex])
solution: Initially the pressure difference between water and oil can be given as [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{w}+(1000 &\times 9.81 \times 1.5)+(13550 \times 9.81 \times 20 \\ \left.\times 10^{-2}\right)-(900 &\times 9.81 \times 3)=p_{0}\\ \Rightarrow \; p_{w t}+14715+26585.1-26487=p_{0} \\ \Rightarrow \quad p_{0}-p_{w}&=14813.1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad P_{0}-P_{w}&=14.8 \mathrm{kPa} &\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] To make the same level of mercury in both the limbs, the level of mercury should be decreased by 10 cm in right limb and increased by 10cm in lett limb [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{w t}+(1000 \times 9.81 &\times 1.6)-(900 \times 9.81 \times 2.9)=p_{0}\\ \Rightarrow \quad P_{0}-p_{w t}&=-9.9 \mathrm{kPa} &\ldots(ii)\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Subtracting (ii) from (i) we get [latex] \begin{array}{l} P_{W}-P_{N}=14.8+99 \\ P_{\mathrm{w} t}-P_{\mathrm{w}}=24.7 \mathrm{kPa} \text { (increase) } \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 205 A hydraulic jump takes place in a triangular channel of vertex angle 90[latex]^{\circ}[/latex], as
shown in figure. The discharge is 1 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] and the pre-jump depth is 0.5 m. What will be the post-jump depth ? (Take g = 981 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex])
solution: Specific force will remain constant on both sides of hydraulic jump. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \frac{Q^{2}}{g A_{1}}+A_{1} \bar{Z}_{1} &=\frac{Q^{2}}{g A_{2}}+A_{2} \bar{Z}_{2} \\ A_{1} &=y_{1}^{2} ; A_{2}=y_{2}^{2} \\ \bar{Z}_{1} &=\left(\frac{y_{1}}{3}\right) ; \quad \bar{Z}_{2}=\left(\frac{y_{2}}{3}\right) \\ \text{Given}\quad Q &=1 \mathrm{m}^{3 / \mathrm{s}} ; y_{1}=0.5 \mathrm{m}\\ \therefore \frac{(1)^{2}}{9.81 \times(0.5)^{2}}&+(0.5)^{2} \times\left(\frac{0.5}{3}\right) \\ &=\frac{(1)^{2}}{9.81 \times y_{2}^{2}}+\left(y_{2}\right)^{2} \times\left(\frac{y_{2}}{3}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \quad 0.4494&=\frac{0.1019}{y_{2}^{2}}+\frac{y_{2}^{3}}{3} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] By hit and trial, we get [latex]y_{2}=1.02 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question:
Question 206 A horizontal jet strikes a frictionless vertical plate (the plan view is shown in the
figure). It is then divided into two parts, as shown in the figure. If the impact loss
is neglected, what is the value of [latex]\theta[/latex]?
solution: From continuity equation, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} & & Q_{0}=Q_{1}+Q_{2} \\ \Rightarrow & & Q_{0}=0.25 Q_{0}+Q_{2} \\ \Rightarrow & & Q_{2}=0.75 Q_{0} \end{aligned}[/latex] since, the impact losses are neglected, the velocity will remain unchanged in the direction of [latex] Q_{1}[/latex] and [latex]Q_{2} [/latex] [latex] \text{i.e.},\quad V_{0}=V_{1}=V_{2} [/latex] Applying impulse momentum equation, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho Q_{0} V_{0} \sin \theta&=\rho Q_{2} V_{2}-\rho Q_{1} V_{1} \\ \Rightarrow \quad Q_{0} \sin \theta&=0.75 Q_{0}-0.25 Q_{0} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sin \theta&=1 / 2 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \theta&=30^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 207 A laboratory model of a river is built to a geometric scale of 1:100. The fluid
used in the model is oil of mass density 900 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. The highest flood in the river is 10,000 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s. The corresponding discharge in the model shall be
solution: Froude model law will be applicable in this case. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{Q_{m}}{Q_{p}}&=\frac{\left(L_{m}\right)^{3} / T_{m}}{\left(L_{p}\right)^{3} / T_{D}} \qquad\left[\because \frac{L_{m}}{T_{m}}=V_{m}\right]\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{Q_{m}}{Q_{p}}&=\frac{V_{m}\left(L_{m}\right)^{2}}{V_{p}\left(L_{p}\right)^{2}} \quad\left[\because v_{1}=\sqrt{L}\right] \\ \Rightarrow \frac{Q_{m}}{Q_{p}}&=\left(\frac{L_{m}}{L_{D}}\right)^{5 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad Q_{m}&=Q_{p} \times\left(\frac{L_{m}}{L_{p}}\right)^{5 / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad Q_{m}&=10.000 \times\left(\frac{1}{100}\right)^{5 / 2} \\ &=0.1 \mathrm{m}^{3}/s \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 208 A flat plate is kept in an infinite fluid medium. The fluid has a uniform free-stream
velocity parallel to the plate. For the laminar boundary layer formed on the plate, pick the correct option matching Columns I and II.

Question 209 For a two-dimensional irrotational flow, the velocity potential defined as [latex]\phi =ln(x^{2}+y^{2})[/latex] . Which of the following is a possible stream function, [latex]\psi[/latex] for this flow ?
solution:
We know that [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial \psi}{\partial y} &=\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{\partial y}{\partial y} &=\frac{\partial}{\partial x} \log _{e}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)\\
 \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial y}&=\frac{2 x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \\
\end{aligned}[/latex] Integrating both sides, we get [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\psi&=\int \frac{2 x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} d y+C\\
 \Rightarrow \quad \Psi&=2 x\times \frac{1}{x} \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)+C \\
 \Rightarrow \quad \Psi&=2 \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)+C 
\end{aligned}[/latex] However, it may be noted that 'C' is a function of x

question:
Question 210 A pump can lift water at a discharge of 0.15[latex]m^{3}/s[/latex] to a head of 25 m. The critical cavitation number ([latex]\sigma _{c}[/latex]) for the pump is found to be 0.144. The pump is to be installed at a location where the barometric pressure is 9.8 m of water and the
vapour pressure of water is 0.30 of water. The intake pipe friction loss is 0.40 m.
Using the minimum value of NPSH (Net Positive Suction Head), the maximum
allowable elevation above the sump water surface at which the pump can be
located is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma_{c} &=\text { NPSH/H } \\ \therefore \quad 0.144 &=\frac{\text { NPSH }}{25} \\ \therefore \quad \text { NPSH } &=3.6 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { NPSH } &=H_{\text {atm }}-H_{v}-h_{s}-h_{L} \\ 3.6 &=9.8-0.3-h_{s}-0.4 \\ \therefore \quad h_{s} &=5.5 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 212 Velocity distribution in a boundary layer flow over a plate is given by [latex](u/u_{m})=1.5 \eta[/latex] where, [latex]\eta =y/\delta[/latex]; y is the distance measured normal to the plate; [latex]\delta[/latex] is the boundary layer thickness; and [latex]u_m[/latex] is the maximum velocity at [latex]y =\delta[/latex]. If the shear stress [latex]\tau[/latex], acting on the plate is given by [latex]\tau =K(\mu u_{m})\delta[/latex] where, [latex]\mu[/latex] is the dynamic viscosity of the fluid, K takes the value of
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given, } \frac{u}{u_{m}}=1.5 \eta ; \; \; &\;\eta=\frac{y}{\delta} \\ \therefore \quad u &=1.5 u_{m} \times \frac{y}{\delta} \\ \frac{d u}{d y} &=1.5 \frac{u_{m}}{\delta} \\ \text { Now, }\quad \tau&=\mu \frac{d u}{d y}=1.5 \mu \frac{u_{m}}{\delta} \\ \therefore \quad k &=1.5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 213 The force 'F' required at equilibrium on the semi-cylindrical gate shown below is
solution: Depth of water (H)=2 m Consider unit width, of cylinder, [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{H} &=\rho g \bar{h} A_{h} \\ &=1000 \times 9.81 \times\left(\frac{2}{2}\right) \times(2 \times 1) \\ &=19.62 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \text { width } \end{aligned}[/latex] Vertical component, [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{v}&=\rho g(\text { volume })\\ &=1000 \times 9.81\left(\frac{\pi R^{2}}{2} \times 1\right) \\ &=15.41 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m} \text { width } \end{aligned}[/latex] location of center of pressure of [latex]F_{h} [/latex] [latex] h^{*}=\frac{2}{3} H=\frac{4}{3} m [/latex] location of center of pressure of [latex]F_{v} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \bar{x}=\frac{4 R}{3 \pi}=\frac{4 \times 1}{3 \pi}=0.424 \mathrm{m} [/latex] Moment about hinge, [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad F_{H} \times\left(h^{*}-\bar{h}\right)&=F_{V} \times \bar{x}+F \times 1 \\ \therefore 19.62 \times\left(\frac{4}{3}-1\right)&=15.41 \times 0.424+F \times 1 \\ \therefore \quad F&=0 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 214 In a 1/50 model of a spillway, the discharge was measured to be 0.3 [latex]m^{3}/sec[/latex]. The corresponding prototype discharge in [latex]m^{3}/sec[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_{r} &=L_{r}^{25} \\ \frac{Q_{\mathrm{p}}}{Q_{m}} &=\left(\frac{L_{p}}{L_{m}}\right)^{25}(50)^{25} \\ \therefore \quad Q_{p} &=0.3 \times(50)^{25}=5303.3 \mathrm{m}^{3 / \mathrm{s}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 215 A trapezoidal channel with bottom width of 3 m and side slope of IV:1.5H carries a discharge of 8.0 [latex]m^3/sec[/latex] with the flow depth of 1.5 m. The Froude number of the flow is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q&=8 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ A&=\frac{1}{2}(3+7.5) \times 1.5=7.875 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ V&=\frac{Q}{\mathrm{A}}=\frac{8}{7.875}=1.015 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\\ \text{Now}\quad \frac{1}{1.5}&=\frac{1.5}{x} \\ x&=2.25\\ T&=3+2 \times 2.25=7.5 \mathrm{m} \\ D&=\frac{A}{T}=\frac{7.875}{7.5}=1.05 \\ F&=\frac{V}{\sqrt{\mathrm{g} \mathrm{D}}}=\frac{1.05}{\sqrt{9.81 \times 1.05}}=0.316 \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence no any option is correct.
